If you change one of these variables, the fringe display is not updated in existing windows showing the buffer, unless you call set-window-buffer again in each affected window. You can also use set-window-fringes to control the fringe display in individual windows.

The accepted keyword values are :bindtodevice, etc. For the complete list, see Network Options. This form returns non-nil if that particular network option is supported by make-network-process (or set-network-process-option).
The action alist passed in each function call is:
The action code tells

The actual completion is done by passing the completion table collection and the completion predicate predicate to the function try-completion (see Basic Completion). This happens in certain commands bound in the local keymaps used for completion. Some of these commands also call test-completion. Thus, if predicate is non-nil, it should be compatible with collection and completion-ignore-case. See Definition of test-completion.
The actual vertical scroll position must always correspond to an integral number of pixels, so the value you specify is rounded accordingly.
The address of the buffer contents. The buffer contents is a linear C array of char, with the gap somewhere in its midst.

The advantage of dynamic function loading is that loading the file should become faster. This is a good thing for a file which contains many separate user-callable functions, if using one of them does not imply you will probably also use the rest. A specialized mode which provides many keyboard commands often has that usage pattern: a user may invoke the mode, but use only a few of the commands it provides.
The advantage of this formulation is that it reuses the indentation of the previous "else", rather than going all the way back to the first "if" of the sequence.
The advantage of using this variable rather than an ordinary global variable is that the data will never carry over to a subsequent command invocation.
The alist containing the structured data that have been unpacked so far, or the entire structure being packed. You can use bindat-get-field to access specific fields of this structure.

The alist describes which parameters were specified in geom, and gives the values specified for them. Each element looks like (parameter . value). The possible parameter values are left, top, width, and height.
The alist of this window’s parameters.
The alt modifier.
The angle in degrees by which the x-axis of the ellipse is rotated relative to the x-axis of the current coordinate system.
The answers and their meanings, even ‘

The appearance of child frames is largely dependent on the parameters provided via alist. It is advisable to use at least ratios to specify the size (see Size Parameters) and the position (see Position Parameters) of the child frame, and to add a keep-ratio parameter (see Frame Interaction Parameters), in order to make sure that the child frame remains visible. For other parameters that should be considered see Child Frames.

The appearance of the keyword &optional in the argument list indicates that the subsequent arguments may be omitted (omitted arguments default to nil). Do not write &optional when you call the function.

The applicable methods are sorted into the order in which they will be combined. The method whose left-most argument specializer is the most specific one will come first in the order. (Specifying :argument-precedence-order as part of cl-defmethod overrides that, as described above.) If the method body calls cl-call-next-method, the next most-specific method will run. If there are applicable :around methods, the most-specific of them will run first; it should call cl-call-next-method to run any of the less specific :around methods. Next, the :before methods run in the order of their specificity, followed by the primary method, and lastly the :after methods in the reverse order of their specificity.
The appropriate comment syntax settings for C++ can be as follows:

The argument name can also be a predicate function. The predicate is called for every directory examined by the function, starting from file (even if file is not a directory). It is called with one argument (the file or directory) and should return non-nil if that directory is the one it is looking for.
The argument accept-defaults controls checking for default bindings, as in lookup-key (above).
The argument accept-defaults controls checking for default bindings, as in lookup-key (see Functions for Key Lookup).

The argument action can also have a non-nil, non-list value. This has the special meaning that the buffer should be displayed in a window other than the selected one, even if the selected window is already displaying it. If called interactively with a prefix argument, action is t. Lisp programs should always supply a list value.

The argument <var>actor</var> says how to act on the answers that the user gives. It should be a function of one argument, and it is called with each object that the user says yes for. Its argument is always an object obtained from <var>list</var>.
The argument align specifies the positioning of the bitmap relative to the range of rows where it is used; the default is to center the bitmap. The allowed values are top, center, or bottom.

The argument area specifies whether to put the image in a margin. If it is left-margin, the image appears in the left margin; right-margin specifies the right margin. If area is nil or omitted, the image is displayed at point within the buffer’s text.
The argument <var>args</var> is a list of keyword/argument pairs. The following keywords are accepted:
The argument auto-mode-list is a list of regular expressions to add to the variable auto-mode-alist. They are added by the execution of the define-generic-mode form, not by expanding the macro call.

The argument bits specifies the image to use. It should be either a string or a vector of integers, where each element (an integer) corresponds to one row of the bitmap. Each bit of an integer corresponds to one pixel of the bitmap, where the low bit corresponds to the rightmost pixel of the bitmap. (Note that this order of bits is opposite of the order in XBM images; see XBM Images.)

The argument buf can be a NULL pointer, in which case the function stores in *len the number of bytes required for storing the contents of arg, and returns true. This is how you can determine the size of buf needed to store a particular string: first call copy_string_contents with NULL as buf, then allocate enough memory to hold the number of bytes stored by the function in *len, and call the function again with non-NULLbuf to actually perform the text copying.

The argument buffer-or-name specifies the temporary buffer. It can be either a buffer, which must already exist, or a string, in which case a buffer of that name is created, if necessary. The buffer is marked as unmodified and read-only when with-temp-buffer-window exits.
The argument <var>character-set</var> is a string, like the inside of a ‘
The argument <var>color</var> must be a valid color name.

The argument command-loop, if non-nil, means that this key sequence is being read by something that will read commands one after another. It should be nil if the caller will read just one key sequence.
The argument command can be any object; it is compared with all keymap entries using eq.

The argument comment-list is a list in which each element is either a character, a string of one or two characters, or a cons cell. A character or a string is set up in the mode’s syntax table as a comment starter. If the entry is a cons cell, the CAR is set up as a comment starter and the CDR as a comment ender. (Use nil for the latter if you want comments to end at the end of the line.) Note that the syntax table mechanism has limitations about what comment starters and enders are actually possible. See Syntax Tables.

The argument count is a repeat count; kbdmacro is executed that many times. If count is omitted or nil, kbdmacro is executed once. If it is 0, kbdmacro is executed over and over until it encounters an error or a failing search.

The argument current-group is a flag that makes a difference when you are running a job-control shell as an Emacs subprocess. If it is non-nil, then the signal is sent to the current process-group of the terminal that Emacs uses to communicate with the subprocess. If the process is a job-control shell, this means the shell’s current subjob. If current-group is nil, the signal is sent to the process group of the immediate subprocess of Emacs. If the subprocess is a job-control shell, this is the shell itself. If current-group is lambda, the signal is sent to the process-group that owns the terminal, but only if it is not the shell itself.
The argument data is a way to arrange for arbitrary additional data to be passed to func when it is called. Whatever pointer is passed to make_function will be passed unaltered to func.

The argument default specifies default values to make available through the history commands. It should be a string, a list of strings, or nil. The string or strings become the minibuffer’s “future history”, available to the user with
trans-unit.target: El argumento default especifica los valores predeterminados para que estén disponibles a través de los comandos del historial. Debe ser una cadena, una lista de cadenas o nil . La cadena o cadenas se convierten en el "historial futuro" del minibúfer, disponible para el usuario con

trans-unit.source: The argument default specifies what to return if the user enters null input. It can be a symbol, a string or a list of strings. If it is a string, read-command interns it before returning it. If it is a list, read-command interns the first element of this list. If default is nil, that means no default has been specified; then if the user enters null input, the return value is (intern ""), that is, a symbol whose name is an empty string, and whose printed representation is ## (see Symbol Type).
trans-unit.target: El argumento default especifica qué devolver si el usuario ingresa una entrada nula. Puede ser un símbolo, una cadena o una lista de cadenas. Si es una cadena, read-command la interna antes de devolverla. Si se trata de una lista, read-command internará el primer elemento de esta lista. Si el default es nil , eso significa que no se ha especificado ningún valor predeterminado; luego, si el usuario ingresa una entrada nula, el valor de retorno es (intern "") , es decir, un símbolo cuyo nombre es una cadena vacía y cuya representación impresa es ## (ver Tipo de símbolo ).

trans-unit.source: The argument directory specifies the directory to use for completing relative file names. It should be an absolute directory name. If the variable insert-default-directory is non-nil, directory is also inserted in the minibuffer as initial input. It defaults to the current buffer’s value of default-directory.
trans-unit.target: El directory argumentos especifica el directorio que se utilizará para completar los nombres de archivos relativos. Debe ser un nombre de directorio absoluto. Si la variable insert-default-directory no es nil , el directory también se inserta en el minibúfer como entrada inicial. Tiene como valor default-directory el valor de directorio predeterminado del búfer actual .

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>doc</var> specifies the documentation string for the variable.
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>doc</var> especifica la cadena de documentación de la variable.

trans-unit.source: The argument docstring is the documentation string for the function. Specifying the documentation string in the call to autoload makes it possible to look at the documentation without loading the function’s real definition. Normally, this should be identical to the documentation string in the function definition itself. If it isn’t, the function definition’s documentation string takes effect when it is loaded.
trans-unit.target: El argumento docstring es la cadena de documentación de la función. La especificación de la cadena de documentación en la llamada a autoload permite ver la documentación sin cargar la definición real de la función. Normalmente, esto debería ser idéntico a la cadena de documentación en la propia definición de la función. Si no es así, la cadena de documentación de la definición de función entra en vigor cuando se carga.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>docstring</var> specifies the documentation string for the function. It should be either an
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>docstring</var> especifica la cadena de documentación de la función. Debería ser un

trans-unit.source: The argument docstring specifies the documentation string for the new mode. define-derived-mode adds some general information about the mode’s hook, followed by the mode’s keymap, at the end of this documentation string. If you omit docstring, define-derived-mode generates a documentation string.
trans-unit.target: El argumento docstring especifica la cadena de documentación para el nuevo modo. define-derived-mode agrega información general sobre el gancho del modo, seguido del mapa de teclas del modo, al final de esta cadena de documentación. Si omite la docstring , el modo define-derived-mode genera una cadena de documentación.

trans-unit.source: The argument error-symbol must be an error symbol—a symbol defined with define-error. This is how Emacs Lisp classifies different sorts of errors. See Error Symbols, for a description of error symbols, error conditions and condition names.
trans-unit.target: El argumento error-symbol debe ser un símbolo de error, un símbolo definido con define-error . Así es como Emacs Lisp clasifica diferentes tipos de errores. Consulte Símbolos de error para obtener una descripción de los símbolos de error, las condiciones de error y los nombres de las condiciones.

trans-unit.source: The argument event may be an entire event object, or just an event type. If event is a symbol that has never been used in an event that has been read as input in the current Emacs session, then event-modifiers can return nil, even when event actually has modifiers.
trans-unit.target: El event o de argumento puede ser un objeto de evento completo o simplemente un tipo de evento. Si event o es un símbolo que nunca se ha utilizado en un evento que se ha leído como entrada en la sesión actual de Emacs, entonces event-modifiers pueden devolver nil , incluso cuando el event o en realidad tiene modificadores.

trans-unit.source: The argument file may be either a directory or a file specification including wildcard characters. If wildcard is non-nil, that means treat file as a file specification with wildcards.
trans-unit.target: El file argumentos puede ser un directorio o una especificación de archivo que incluya caracteres comodín. Si el wildcard no es nil , eso significa tratar el file como una especificación de archivo con comodines.

trans-unit.source: The argument force also has an effect if the line isn’t long enough to reach column column; if it is t, that means to add whitespace at the end of the line to reach that column.
trans-unit.target: La force argumento también tiene un efecto si la línea no es lo suficientemente larga para alcanzar la columna de la column a ; si es t , eso significa agregar espacios en blanco al final de la línea para llegar a esa columna.

trans-unit.source: The argument format is a list of format names. If format is nil, no conversion takes place. Interactively, typing just
trans-unit.target: El format o del argumento es una lista de nombres de formato. Si el format o es nil , no se realiza ninguna conversión. Interactivamente, escribiendo solo

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>function</var> must be a function that can take one argument and returns a sequence of characters: a string, a vector, or a list. The argument <var>sequence</var> can be any kind of sequence except a char-table; that is, a list, a vector, a bool-vector, or a string.
trans-unit.target: La <var>function</var> argumento debe ser una función que pueda tomar un argumento y devolver una secuencia de caracteres: una cadena, un vector o una lista. La <var>sequence</var> argumentos puede ser cualquier tipo de secuencia excepto una tabla de caracteres; es decir, una lista, un vector, un bool-vector o una cadena.

trans-unit.source: The argument function must be either a Lisp function or a primitive function. Special forms and macros are not allowed, because they make sense only when given the unevaluated argument expressions. funcall cannot provide these because, as we saw above, it never knows them in the first place.
trans-unit.target: La function argumento debe ser una función Lisp o una función primitiva. No se permiten macros ni formas especiales, porque sólo tienen sentido cuando se les dan las expresiones de argumento no evaluadas. funcall no puede proporcionarlos porque, como vimos anteriormente, nunca los conoce en primer lugar.

trans-unit.source: The argument help-line should be a single-line summary of the alternatives in help-map. In the current version of Emacs, this argument is used only if you set the option three-step-help to t.
trans-unit.target: La help-line argumento debe ser un resumen de una sola línea de las alternativas en help-map . En la versión actual de Emacs, este argumento se usa solo si establece la opción three-step-help en t .

trans-unit.source: The argument history specifies a history list variable to use for saving the input and for history commands used in the minibuffer. It defaults to minibuffer-history. You can optionally specify a starting position in the history list as well. See Minibuffer History.
trans-unit.target: El argumento history especifica una variable de lista de historial que se utilizará para guardar la entrada y para los comandos de historial utilizados en el minibúfer. Su valor predeterminado es minibuffer-history . Opcionalmente, también puede especificar una posición inicial en la lista del historial. Consulte Historial del minibúfer .

trans-unit.source: The argument history specifies which history list variable to use for saving the input and for minibuffer history commands. It defaults to minibuffer-history. See Minibuffer History.
trans-unit.target: El argumento history especifica qué variable de lista de historial usar para guardar la entrada y para los comandos del historial del minibúfer. Su valor predeterminado es minibuffer-history . Consulte Historial del minibúfer .

trans-unit.source: The argument hook is a function or nil. If hook is non-nil, then it is called with no arguments after the abbrev is replaced with expansion; point is located at the end of expansion when hook is called.
trans-unit.target: El hook argumento es una función o nil . Si hook no es nil , entonces se llama sin argumentos después de que la abreviatura se reemplaza por expansion ; el punto se encuentra al final de la expansion cuando se llama al hook .

trans-unit.source: The argument how, if non-nil specifies explicitly the style of justification. It can be left, right, full, center, or none. If it is t, that means to follow specified justification style (see current-justification, below). nil means to do full justification.
trans-unit.target: El argumento how , si no es nil especifica explícitamente el estilo de justificación. Puede ser left , right , full , center o none . Si es t , eso significa seguir el estilo de justificación especificado (ver current-justification , más abajo). nil significa hacer una justificación completa.

trans-unit.source: The argument image must be an image descriptor, perhaps returned by create-image or stored by defimage.
trans-unit.target: El argumento image debe ser un descriptor de imagen, quizás devuelto por create-image o almacenado por defimage .

trans-unit.source: The argument initial is mostly deprecated; we recommend using a non-nil value only in conjunction with specifying a cons cell for history. See Initial Input. For default input, use default instead.
trans-unit.target: La initial argumento está en desuso en su mayoría; recomendamos usar un valor que no sea nil solo junto con la especificación de una celda de contras para el history . Consulte Entrada inicial . Para la entrada predeterminada, use default en su lugar.

trans-unit.source: The argument keys, if given, should be a vector which specifies the sequence of events to supply if the command inquires which events were used to invoke it. If keys is omitted or nil, the default is the return value of this-command-keys-vector. See Definition of this-command-keys-vector.
trans-unit.target: Las keys argumentos , si se dan, deben ser un vector que especifique la secuencia de eventos a suministrar si el comando pregunta qué eventos se usaron para invocarlo. Si keys se omite o es nil , el valor predeterminado es el valor de retorno de this-command-keys-vector . Consulte Definición de this-command-keys-vector .

trans-unit.source: The argument keyword-list is a list of keywords to highlight with font-lock-keyword-face. Each keyword should be a string. Meanwhile, font-lock-list is a list of additional expressions to highlight. Each element of this list should have the same form as an element of font-lock-keywords. See Search-based Fontification.
trans-unit.target: El argumento keyword-list es una lista de palabras clave para destacar con font-lock-keyword-face . Cada palabra clave debe ser una cadena. Mientras tanto, font-lock-list es una lista de expresiones adicionales para resaltar. Cada elemento de esta lista debe tener la misma forma que un elemento de font-lock-keywords . Consulte Fontificación basada en búsquedas .

trans-unit.source: The argument kind should be either the symbol interactive or the symbol any. If it is interactive, then called-interactively-p returns t only if the call was made directly by the user—e.g., if the user typed a key sequence bound to the calling function, but not if the user ran a keyboard macro that called the function (see Keyboard Macros). If kind is any, called-interactively-p returns t for any kind of interactive call, including keyboard macros.
trans-unit.target: El kind argumento debe ser el símbolo interactive o el símbolo any . Si es interactive , entonces called-interactively-p devuelve t solo si el usuario realizó la llamada directamente; por ejemplo, si el usuario escribió una secuencia de teclas vinculada a la función que llama, pero no si el usuario ejecutó una macro de teclado que llamó la función (consulte Macros del teclado ). Si kind es any , called-interactively-p devuelve t para cualquier tipo de llamada interactiva, incluidas las macros de teclado.

trans-unit.source: The argument left specifies the width in pixels of the left fringe, and likewise right for the right fringe. A value of nil for either one stands for the default width. If outside-margins is non-nil, that specifies that fringes should appear outside of the display margins.
trans-unit.target: El argumento left especifica el ancho en píxeles de la franja izquierda, e igualmente a la right para la franja derecha. Un valor de nil para cualquiera de ellos representa el ancho predeterminado. Si outside-margins no son nil , eso especifica que las franjas deben aparecer fuera de los márgenes de visualización.

trans-unit.source: The argument lexical specifies the scoping rule for local variables (see Variable Scoping). If it is omitted or nil, that means to evaluate form using the default dynamic scoping rule. If it is t, that means to use the lexical scoping rule. The value of lexical can also be a non-empty alist specifying a particular lexical environment for lexical bindings; however, this feature is only useful for specialized purposes, such as in Emacs Lisp debuggers. See Lexical Binding.
trans-unit.target: El argumento lexical especifica la regla de alcance para las variables locales (consulte Alcance de variables ). Si se omite o es nil , eso significa evaluar el form ulario utilizando la regla de alcance dinámica predeterminada. Si es t , eso significa usar la regla de alcance léxico. El valor de lexical también puede ser una lista no vacía que especifique un entorno léxico particular para enlaces léxicos; sin embargo, esta característica solo es útil para propósitos especializados, como en los depuradores Emacs Lisp. Consulte Enlace léxico .

trans-unit.source: The argument limit specifies the bound to the search, and should be a position in the current buffer. No match extending after that position is accepted. If limit is omitted or nil, it defaults to the end of the accessible portion of the buffer.
trans-unit.target: El limit argumento especifica el límite de la búsqueda y debe ser una posición en el búfer actual. No se acepta ninguna coincidencia que se extienda después de esa posición. Si se omite el limit o es nil , el valor predeterminado es el final de la parte accesible del búfer.

trans-unit.source: The argument members is a list specifying an initial set of customization items to be members of the group. However, most often members is nil, and you specify the group’s members by using the :group keyword when defining those members.
trans-unit.target: Los members argumento es una lista que especifica un conjunto inicial de elementos de personalización para ser miembros del grupo. Sin embargo, la mayoría de las veces members es nil y usted especifica los miembros del grupo usando la palabra clave :group al definir esos miembros.

trans-unit.source: The argument menu says what to display in the menu. It can be a keymap or a list of keymaps (see Menu Keymaps). In this case, the return value is the list of events corresponding to the user’s choice. This list has more than one element if the choice occurred in a submenu. (Note that x-popup-menu does not actually execute the command bound to that sequence of events.) On text terminals and toolkits that support menu titles, the title is taken from the prompt string of menu if menu is a keymap, or from the prompt string of the first keymap in menu if it is a list of keymaps (see Defining Menus).
trans-unit.target: El menu argumentos dice qué mostrar en el menú. Puede ser un mapa de teclas o una lista de mapas de teclas (consulte Mapas de teclas de menú ). En este caso, el valor de retorno es la lista de eventos correspondiente a la elección del usuario. Esta lista tiene más de un elemento si la elección ocurrió en un submenú. (Tenga en cuenta que x-popup-menu en realidad no ejecuta el comando vinculado a esa secuencia de eventos). En terminales de texto y kits de herramientas que admiten títulos de menú, el título se toma de la cadena de solicitud del menu si el menu es un mapa de teclas, o de la cadena de solicitud del primer mapa de teclas en el menu si es una lista de mapas de teclas (consulte Definición de menús ).

trans-unit.source: The argument meta controls support for input character codes above 127. If meta is t, Emacs converts characters with the 8th bit set into Meta characters. If meta is nil, Emacs disregards the 8th bit; this is necessary when the terminal uses it as a parity bit. If meta is neither t nor nil, Emacs uses all 8 bits of input unchanged. This is good for terminals that use 8-bit character sets.
trans-unit.target: El argumento meta controla el soporte para códigos de caracteres de entrada por encima de 127. Si meta es t , Emacs convierte los caracteres con el 8º bit establecido en metacaracteres. Si meta es nil , Emacs ignora el octavo bit; esto es necesario cuando el terminal lo usa como bit de paridad. Si meta no es ni t ni nil , Emacs usa los 8 bits de entrada sin cambios. Esto es bueno para terminales que usan juegos de caracteres de 8 bits.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>millisec</var> is obsolete (and should not be used), because <var>seconds</var> can be floating point to specify waiting a fractional number of seconds. If <var>seconds</var> is 0, the function accepts whatever output is pending but does not wait.
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>millisec</var> es obsoleto (y no debe usarse), porque los <var>seconds</var> pueden ser un punto flotante para especificar la espera de una fracción de segundos. Si los <var>seconds</var> son 0, la función acepta cualquier salida pendiente pero no espera.

trans-unit.source: The argument mode should be an integer which specifies the permissions, similar to set-file-modes above. Only the lowest 9 bits are meaningful.
trans-unit.target: El mode argumento debe ser un número entero que especifique los permisos, similar a set-file-modes anterior. Solo los 9 bits más bajos son significativos.

trans-unit.source: The argument name may also be a symbol; in that case, the function returns name if name is interned in the specified obarray, and otherwise nil.
trans-unit.target: El name argumento también puede ser un símbolo; en ese caso, la función devuelve name si name está incluido en el obarray especificado y, en caso contrario, nil .

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>noerror</var> only affects valid searches which fail to find a match. Invalid arguments cause errors regardless of <var>noerror</var>.
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>noerror</var> solo afecta las búsquedas válidas que no encuentran una coincidencia. Los argumentos no válidos provocan errores independientemente de que no <var>noerror</var> errores .

trans-unit.source: The argument object can be a function name, a lambda expression (see Lambda Expressions), or a byte-code object (see Byte-Code Objects). If it is a lambda expression, disassemble compiles it and disassembles the resulting compiled code.
trans-unit.target: El object argumento puede ser un nombre de función, una expresión lambda (consulte Expresiones Lambda ) o un objeto de código byte (consulte Objetos de código byte ). Si es una expresión lambda, disassemble compila y desensambla el código compilado resultante.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>object</var> may be a string, a buffer, or a window. If it is a window, then the buffer displayed in that window is used for text properties and overlays, but only the overlays active for that window are considered. If <var>object</var> is a buffer, then overlays in that buffer are considered first, in order of decreasing priority, followed by the text properties. If <var>object</var> is a string, only text properties are considered, since strings never have overlays.
trans-unit.target: El <var>object</var> argumento puede ser una cadena, un búfer o una ventana. Si es una ventana, entonces el búfer que se muestra en esa ventana se usa para propiedades de texto y superposiciones, pero solo se consideran las superposiciones activas para esa ventana. Si el <var>object</var> es un búfer, las superposiciones en ese búfer se consideran primero, en orden de prioridad decreciente, seguidas de las propiedades del texto. Si el <var>object</var> es una cadena, solo se consideran las propiedades del texto, ya que las cadenas nunca tienen superposiciones.

trans-unit.source: The argument offsets is either nil or a cons cell of the form (hscroll . tab-offset). Here hscroll is the number of columns not being displayed at the left margin; most callers get this by calling window-hscroll. Meanwhile, tab-offset is the offset between column numbers on the screen and column numbers in the buffer. This can be nonzero in a continuation line, when the previous screen lines’ widths do not add up to a multiple of tab-width. It is always zero in a non-continuation line.
trans-unit.target: El argumento offsets es nil o una celda de contras de la forma (hscroll . tab-offset) . Aquí hscroll es el número de columnas que no se muestran en el margen izquierdo; la mayoría de las personas que llaman obtienen esto llamando a window-hscroll . Mientras tanto, tab-offset es el desplazamiento entre los números de columna en la pantalla y los números de columna en el búfer. Esto puede ser distinto de cero en una línea de continuación, cuando los anchos de las líneas de pantalla anteriores no suman un múltiplo del tab-width de tabulación . Siempre es cero en una línea de no continuación.

trans-unit.source: The argument operation is a symbol; it should be one of write-region, start-process, call-process, call-process-region, insert-file-contents, or open-network-stream. These are the names of the Emacs I/O primitives that can do character code and eol conversion.
trans-unit.target: La operation argumento es un símbolo; debe ser uno de los siguientes: write-region , start-process , call-process , call-process-region , insert-file-contents o open-network-stream . Estos son los nombres de las primitivas de E / S de Emacs que pueden realizar conversión de código de caracteres y eol.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>partial-filename</var> must be a file name containing no directory part and no slash (or backslash on some systems). The current buffer’s default directory is prepended to <var>directory</var>, if <var>directory</var> is not absolute.
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>partial-filename</var> debe ser un nombre de archivo que no contenga parte de directorio ni barra diagonal (o barra invertida en algunos sistemas). El directorio predeterminado del búfer actual se antepone al <var>directory</var> , si el <var>directory</var> no es absoluto.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>position</var> specifies where on the screen to put the top left corner of the menu. It can be either a mouse button event (which says to put the menu where the user actuated the button) or a list of this form:
trans-unit.target: La <var>position</var> argumento especifica en qué lugar de la pantalla colocar la esquina superior izquierda del menú. Puede ser un evento de botón del mouse (que dice poner el menú donde el usuario accionó el botón) o una lista de este formulario:

trans-unit.source: The argument predicate is the function to use to compare keys. It is called with two arguments, the keys to compare, and should return non-nil if the first key should come before the second in the sorting order. What exactly are the key arguments depends on what startkeyfun and endkeyfun return. If predicate is omitted or nil, it defaults to < if the keys are numbers, to compare-buffer-substrings if the keys are cons cells (whose car and cdr are start and end buffer positions of the key), and to string< otherwise (with keys assumed to be strings).
trans-unit.target: El predicate argumento es la función que se usa para comparar claves. Se llama con dos argumentos, las claves para comparar, y debe devolver un valor distinto de nil si la primera clave debe ir antes que la segunda en el orden de clasificación. Cuáles son exactamente los argumentos clave depende de lo que startkeyfun y endkeyfun . Si el predicate se omite o es nil , el valor predeterminado es < si las claves son números, compare-buffer-substrings si las claves son celdas cons (cuyo car y cdr son posiciones de búfer inicial y final de la clave), y string< caso contrario (se supone que las claves son cadenas).

trans-unit.source: The argument predicate must be a function that accepts two arguments. It is called with two elements of sequence. To get an increasing order sort, the predicate should return non-nil if the first element is “less” than the second, or nil if not.
trans-unit.target: El predicate argumento debe ser una función que acepte dos argumentos. Se llama con dos elementos de sequence . Para obtener una clasificación de orden creciente, el predicate debe devolver un valor distinto de nil si el primer elemento es "menor" que el segundo, o nil si no es así.

trans-unit.source: The argument process must be either a process, a process name, a buffer, a buffer name, or nil. A buffer or buffer name stands for a process through get-buffer-process. nil stands for the process associated with the current buffer. Except with stop-process and continue-process, an error is signaled if process does not identify an active process, or if it represents a network, serial, or pipe connection.
trans-unit.target: El process argumento debe ser un proceso, un nombre de proceso, un búfer, un nombre de búfer o nil . Un búfer o nombre de búfer representa un proceso a través de get-buffer-process . nil representa el proceso asociado con el búfer actual. Excepto con stop-process y continue-process , se indica un error si el process no identifica un proceso activo, o si representa una conexión de red, serie o tubería.

trans-unit.source: The argument prompt is either a string to be displayed in the echo area as a prompt, or nil, meaning not to display a prompt.
trans-unit.target: La prompt argumento es una cadena que se mostrará en el área de eco como una solicitud, o nil , lo que significa que no se mostrará una solicitud.

trans-unit.source: The argument prompt is either a string to be displayed in the echo area as a prompt, or nil, meaning not to display a prompt. The argument continue-echo, if non-nil, means to echo this key as a continuation of the previous key.
trans-unit.target: La prompt argumento es una cadena que se mostrará en el área de eco como una solicitud, o nil , lo que significa que no se mostrará una solicitud. El argumento continue-echo , si no es nil , significa repetir esta clave como una continuación de la clave anterior.

trans-unit.source: The argument prompt should be a string ending with a colon and a space. If default is non-nil, the function inserts it in prompt before the colon to follow the convention for reading from the minibuffer with a default value (see Programming Tips).
trans-unit.target: La prompt argumento debe ser una cadena que termine con dos puntos y un espacio. Si el default no es nil , la función lo inserta en el prompt antes de los dos puntos para seguir la convención para leer desde el minibúfer con un valor predeterminado (consulte Sugerencias de programación ).

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>prompter</var> specifies how to ask each question. If <var>prompter</var> is a string, the question text is computed like this:
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>prompter</var> especifica cómo pedir cada pregunta. Si el <var>prompter</var> es una cadena, el texto de la pregunta se calcula así:

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>props</var> is the new property list. It should be a list whose elements are property names alternating with corresponding values.
trans-unit.target: Los <var>props</var> argumento es la nueva lista de propiedades. Debe ser una lista cuyos elementos sean nombres de propiedades alternados con los valores correspondientes.

trans-unit.source: The argument props specifies which properties to add. It should have the form of a property list (see Property Lists): a list whose elements include the property names followed alternately by the corresponding values.
trans-unit.target: El argumento props especifica qué propiedades agregar. Debe tener la forma de una lista de propiedades (ver Listas de propiedades ): una lista cuyos elementos incluyen los nombres de las propiedades seguidos alternativamente por los valores correspondientes.

trans-unit.source: The argument props specifies which properties to delete. It should have the form of a property list (see Property Lists): a list whose elements are property names alternating with corresponding values. But only the names matter—the values that accompany them are ignored. For example, here’s how to remove the face property.
trans-unit.target: El argumento props especifica qué propiedades eliminar. Debe tener la forma de una lista de propiedades (ver Listas de propiedades ): una lista cuyos elementos son nombres de propiedades que se alternan con los valores correspondientes. Pero sólo importan los nombres: se ignoran los valores que los acompañan. Por ejemplo, aquí se explica cómo eliminar la propiedad de la face .

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>question</var> is the outgoing message that starts the transaction. The argument <var>fn</var> is the function to call when the corresponding answer comes back; it is called with two arguments: <var>closure</var>, and the answer received.
trans-unit.target: La <var>question</var> argumento es el mensaje saliente que inicia la transacción. El argumento <var>fn</var> es la función a llamar cuando regresa la respuesta correspondiente; se llama con dos argumentos: <var>closure</var> y la respuesta recibida.

trans-unit.source: The argument regexp is a regular expression that should match text at the end of the entire answer, but nothing before; that’s how tq-enqueue determines where the answer ends.
trans-unit.target: El argumento regexp es una expresión regular que debe coincidir con el texto al final de la respuesta completa, pero nada antes; así es como tq-enqueue determina dónde termina la respuesta.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>replacements</var> specifies what to replace occurrences with. If it is a string, that string is used. It can also be a list of strings, to be used in cyclic order.
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>replacements</var> especifica con qué reemplazar las ocurrencias. Si es una cadena, se utiliza esa cadena. También puede ser una lista de cadenas, que se utilizará en orden cíclico.

trans-unit.source: The argument runtime is a pointer to a C struct that includes 2 public fields: size, which provides the size of the structure in bytes; and get_environment, which provides a pointer to a function that allows the module initialization function access to the Emacs environment object and its interfaces.
trans-unit.target: El argumento runtime es un puntero a una struct C que incluye 2 campos públicos: size , que proporciona el tamaño de la estructura en bytes; y get_environment , que proporciona un puntero a una función que permite a la función de inicialización del módulo acceder al objeto de entorno de Emacs y sus interfaces.

trans-unit.source: The argument seconds need not be an integer. If it is floating point, sit-for waits for a fractional number of seconds. Some systems support only a whole number of seconds; on these systems, seconds is rounded down.
trans-unit.target: El argumento seconds no necesita ser un número entero. Si es de punto flotante, sit-for espera una fracción de segundos. Algunos sistemas admiten solo un número entero de segundos; en estos sistemas, los seconds se redondean hacia abajo.

trans-unit.source: The argument seconds need not be an integer. If it is floating point, sleep-for waits for a fractional number of seconds. Some systems support only a whole number of seconds; on these systems, seconds is rounded down.
trans-unit.target: El argumento seconds no necesita ser un número entero. Si es de punto flotante, sleep-for espera una fracción de segundos. Algunos sistemas admiten solo un número entero de segundos; en estos sistemas, los seconds se redondean hacia abajo.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>sequence</var> can be any kind of sequence except a char-table; that is, a list, a vector, a bool-vector, or a string. The result is always a list. The length of the result is the same as the length of <var>sequence</var>. For example:
trans-unit.target: La <var>sequence</var> argumentos puede ser cualquier tipo de secuencia excepto una tabla de caracteres; es decir, una lista, un vector, un bool-vector o una cadena. El resultado es siempre una lista. La longitud del resultado es la misma que la longitud de la <var>sequence</var> . Por ejemplo:

trans-unit.source: The argument slice specifies a slice of the image to insert. If slice is nil or omitted the whole image is inserted. Otherwise, slice is a list (x y width height) which specifies the x and y positions and width and height of the image area to insert. Integer values are in units of pixels. A floating-point number in the range 0.0–1.0 stands for that fraction of the width or height of the entire image.
trans-unit.target: El argumento slice especifica un segmento de la imagen que se va a insertar. Si el slice es nil o se omite, se inserta la imagen completa. De lo contrario, slice es una lista (x y width height) que especifica la x y y posiciones y width y height de la zona de imagen a insertar. Los valores enteros están en unidades de píxeles. Un número de punto flotante en el rango de 0.0 a 1.0 representa esa fracción del ancho o alto de la imagen completa.

trans-unit.source: The argument special, if given, means to ignore the prefix argument and not clear it. This is used for executing special events (see Special Events).
trans-unit.target: El argumento special , si se da, significa ignorar el argumento del prefijo y no borrarlo. Se utiliza para ejecutar eventos especiales (ver Eventos especiales ).

trans-unit.source: The argument standard is an expression that specifies the standard value for option. Evaluating the defcustom form evaluates standard, but does not necessarily bind the option to that value. If option already has a default value, it is left unchanged. If the user has already saved a customization for option, the user’s customized value is installed as the default value. Otherwise, the result of evaluating standard is installed as the default value.
trans-unit.target: El argumento standard es una expresión que especifica el valor estándar de la option . La evaluación del formulario defcustom evalúa el standard , pero no necesariamente vincula la opción a ese valor. Si la option ya tiene un valor predeterminado, no se modifica. Si el usuario ya ha guardado una option personalización para , el valor personalizado del usuario se instala como valor predeterminado. De lo contrario, el resultado de la evaluación del standard se instala como valor predeterminado.

trans-unit.source: The argument switch-frame-ok, if non-nil, means that this function should process a switch-frame event if the user switches frames before typing anything. If the user switches frames in the middle of a key sequence, or at the start of the sequence but switch-frame-ok is nil, then the event will be put off until after the current key sequence.
trans-unit.target: El argumento switch-frame-ok , si no es nil , significa que esta función debería procesar un evento de switch-frame si el usuario cambia de marco antes de escribir algo. Si el usuario cambia de fotogramas en medio de una secuencia de teclas, o al comienzo de la secuencia pero switch-frame-ok es nil , el evento se pospondrá hasta después de la secuencia de teclas actual.

trans-unit.source: The argument symbol is not implicitly quoted; add-to-list is an ordinary function, like set and unlike setq. Quote the argument yourself if that is what you want.
trans-unit.target: El symbol argumento no se cita implícitamente; add-to-list es una función ordinaria, como set y a diferencia de setq . Cite el argumento usted mismo si eso es lo que desea.

trans-unit.source: The argument symbol is not implicitly quoted; add-to-ordered-list is an ordinary function, like set and unlike setq. Quote the argument yourself if necessary.
trans-unit.target: El symbol argumento no se cita implícitamente; add-to-ordered-list es una función ordinaria, como set y a diferencia de setq . Cite el argumento usted mismo si es necesario.

trans-unit.source: The argument syntax-descriptor is a syntax descriptor, i.e., a string whose first character is a syntax class designator and whose second and subsequent characters optionally specify a matching character and syntax flags. See Syntax Descriptors. An error is signaled if syntax-descriptor is not a valid syntax descriptor.
trans-unit.target: El argumento syntax-descriptor es un descriptor de sintaxis, es decir, una cadena cuyo primer carácter es un designador de clase de sintaxis y cuyo segundo y los siguientes caracteres especifican opcionalmente un carácter coincidente y banderas de sintaxis. Consulte Descriptores de sintaxis . Se indica un error si syntax-descriptor no es un descriptor de sintaxis válido.

trans-unit.source: The argument thing is a symbol which specifies a kind of syntactic entity. Possibilities include symbol, list, sexp, defun, filename, url, word, sentence, whitespace, line, page, and others.
trans-unit.target: El argumento de thing es un símbolo que especifica un tipo de entidad sintáctica. Las posibilidades incluyen symbol , list a , sexp , defun , filename , url , word , sentence , whitespace , line , page y otros.

trans-unit.source: The argument time, if given, specifies a time to format, instead of the current time. The optional argument zone defaults to the current time zone rule. See Time Zone Rules. The operating system limits the range of time and zone values.
trans-unit.target: La time argumento , si se da, especifica una hora para formatear, en lugar de la hora actual. La zone argumento opcional tiene como valor predeterminado la regla de zona horaria actual. Consulte las reglas de la zona horaria . El sistema operativo limita el rango de valores de zona y hora.

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>time</var>, if given, specifies a time value to analyze instead of the current time. The optional argument <var>zone</var> defaults to the current time zone rule. The operating system limits the range of time and zone values.
trans-unit.target: El <var>time</var> argumento , si se da, especifica un valor de tiempo para analizar en lugar del tiempo actual. La <var>zone</var> argumento opcional tiene como valor predeterminado la regla de zona horaria actual. El sistema operativo limita el rango de valores de zona y hora.

trans-unit.source: The argument value is used as the value to return from that catch.
trans-unit.target: El value argumento se usa como el valor para regresar de esa catch .

trans-unit.source: The argument var is a variable. condition-case does not bind this variable when executing the protected-form, only when it handles an error. At that time, it binds var locally to an error description, which is a list giving the particulars of the error. The error description has the form (error-symbol . data). The handler can refer to this list to decide what to do. For example, if the error is for failure opening a file, the file name is the second element of data—the third element of the error description.
trans-unit.target: El argumento var es una variable. condition-case no vincula esta variable al ejecutar el protected-form , solo cuando maneja un error. En ese momento, vincula var localmente a una descripción de error , que es una lista que proporciona los detalles del error. La descripción del error tiene la forma (error-symbol . data) . El controlador puede consultar esta lista para decidir qué hacer. Por ejemplo, si el error se debe a una falla al abrir un archivo, el nombre del archivo es el segundo elemento de data , el tercer elemento de la descripción del error.

trans-unit.source: The argument visible-ok is handled as with other-buffer, see above. If no suitable buffer can be found, the buffer
trans-unit.target: El argumento visible-ok se maneja como con other-buffer , ver arriba. Si no se puede encontrar un búfer adecuado, el búfer

trans-unit.source: The argument <var>when</var> should be a string indicating when the function was first made obsolete—for example, a date or a release number.
trans-unit.target: El argumento <var>when</var> debe ser una cadena que indique cuándo la función se volvió obsoleta por primera vez, por ejemplo, una fecha o un número de publicación.

trans-unit.source: The argument width is the number of columns available to display text; this affects handling of continuation lines. nil means the actual number of usable text columns in the window, which is equivalent to the value returned by (window-width window).
trans-unit.target: El width argumento es el número de columnas disponibles para mostrar texto; esto afecta el manejo de las líneas de continuación. nil significa el número real de columnas de texto utilizables en la ventana, que es equivalente al valor devuelto por (window-width window) .

trans-unit.source: The argument is a single, highest-level form in a definition. This is like def-body, except it is used to match a single form rather than a list of forms. As a special case, def-form also means that tracing information is not output when the form is executed. See the interactive example.
trans-unit.target: El argumento es una forma única de más alto nivel en una definición. Esto es como def-body , excepto que se usa para hacer coincidir un solo formulario en lugar de una lista de formularios. Como caso especial, def-form también significa que la información de seguimiento no se genera cuando se ejecuta el formulario. Vea el ejemplo interactive .

trans-unit.source: The argument is the body of code in a definition. This is like body, described above, but a definition body must be instrumented with a different Edebug call that looks up information associated with the definition. Use def-body for the highest level list of forms within the definition.
trans-unit.target: El argumento es el cuerpo del código en una definición. Esto es como body , descrito anteriormente, pero un cuerpo de definición debe instrumentarse con una llamada de Edebug diferente que busque información asociada con la definición. Utilice def-body para la lista de formularios de mayor nivel dentro de la definición.

trans-unit.source: The argument must be a cons cell whose car is eql to object.
trans-unit.target: El argumento debe ser una celda de contras cuyo car sea eql al object .

trans-unit.source: The argument must be an instance of a class named struct-type defined with cl-defstruct (see Structures in
trans-unit.target: El argumento debe ser una instancia de una clase denominada struct-type definida con cl-defstruct (ver Estructuras en

trans-unit.source: The argument must be an instance of a class named struct-type defined with cl-defstruct (see Structures in
The argument should be a symbol named string. This specification is equivalent to the quoted symbol, 'symbol, where the name of symbol is the string, but the string form is preferred.
trans-unit.target: El argumento debe ser un símbolo llamado string . Esta especificación es equivalente al símbolo entre comillas, 'symbol , donde el nombre del symbol es la string , pero se prefiere la forma de cadena.

trans-unit.source: The argument should be a vector whose elements must match the <var>elements</var> in the specification. See the backquote example.
trans-unit.target: El argumento debe ser un vector cuyos elementos deben coincidir con los <var>elements</var> de la especificación. Vea el ejemplo de la cita inversa.

trans-unit.source: The argument to byte-compile can also be a lambda expression. In that case, the function returns the corresponding compiled code but does not store it anywhere.
trans-unit.target: El argumento para byte-compile también puede ser una expresión lambda . En ese caso, la función devuelve el código compilado correspondiente pero no lo almacena en ningún lugar.

trans-unit.source: The argument to the :options keywords should be a list of specifications for reasonable keys in the alist. Ordinarily, they are simply atoms, which stand for themselves. For example:
trans-unit.target: El argumento de las palabras clave :options debe ser una lista de especificaciones para claves razonables en la lista. Por lo general, son simplemente átomos, que se representan a sí mismos. Por ejemplo:

trans-unit.source: The argument, a symbol, is the name of an argument of the defining form. However, lambda-list keywords (symbols starting with ‘
trans-unit.target: El argumento, un símbolo, es el nombre de un argumento de la forma definitoria. Sin embargo, las palabras clave de lista lambda (símbolos que comienzan con '

trans-unit.source: The argument, a symbol, is the name of the defining form.
trans-unit.target: El argumento,un smbolo,es el nombre de la forma que lo define.

trans-unit.source: The arguments :before and :around used in the above examples specify how the two functions are composed, since there are many different ways to do it. The added function is also called a piece of advice.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos :before y :around utilizados en los ejemplos anteriores especifican cómo se componen las dos funciones, ya que hay muchas formas diferentes de hacerlo. La función añadida también se denomina consejo .

trans-unit.source: The arguments from, to, and do in this macro are syntactic sugar; they are entirely ignored. The idea is that you will write noise words (such as from, to, and do) in those positions in the macro call.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos from , to y do en esta macro son azúcar sintáctico; son completamente ignorados. La idea es que escriba palabras irrelevantes (como from , to y do ) en esas posiciones en la llamada de macro.

trans-unit.source: The arguments args are a list of keyword/argument pairs. Omitting a keyword is always equivalent to specifying it with value nil.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos args son una lista de pares de palabras clave / argumentos. Omitir una palabra clave siempre equivale a especificarla con un valor nil .

trans-unit.source: The arguments args are a list of keyword/argument pairs. Omitting a keyword is always equivalent to specifying it with value nil. Here are the meaningful keywords:
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos args son una lista de pares de palabras clave / argumentos. Omitir una palabra clave siempre equivale a especificarla con un valor nil . Aquí están las palabras clave significativas:

trans-unit.source: The arguments destination and display control what to do with the output from the subprocess, and whether to update the display as it comes in. For details, see the description of call-process, above. If destination is the integer 0, call-process-region discards the output and returns nil immediately, without waiting for the subprocess to finish (this only works if asynchronous subprocesses are supported; i.e., not on MS-DOS).
trans-unit.target: El destination argumentos y la display controlan qué hacer con la salida del subproceso y si actualizar la pantalla a medida que ingresa. Para obtener más detalles, consulte la descripción del call-process de llamada , más arriba. Si el destination es el entero 0, call-process-region descarta la salida y devuelve nil inmediatamente, sin esperar a que finalice el subproceso (esto solo funciona si se admiten subprocesos asincrónicos; es decir, no en MS-DOS).

trans-unit.source: The arguments front-advance and rear-advance specify the marker insertion type for the start of the overlay and for the end of the overlay, respectively. See Marker Insertion Types. If they are both nil, the default, then the overlay extends to include any text inserted at the beginning, but not text inserted at the end. If front-advance is non-nil, text inserted at the beginning of the overlay is excluded from the overlay. If rear-advance is non-nil, text inserted at the end of the overlay is included in the overlay.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos front-advance y rear-advance especifican el tipo de inserción del marcador para el inicio de la superposición y para el final de la superposición, respectivamente. Consulte Tipos de inserción de marcadores . Si ambos son nil , el valor predeterminado, la superposición se extiende para incluir cualquier texto insertado al principio, pero no el texto insertado al final. Si front-advance no es nil , el texto insertado al principio de la superposición se excluye de la superposición. Si rear-advance no es nil , el texto insertado al final de la superposición se incluye en la superposición.

trans-unit.source: The arguments host and service specify where to connect to; host is the host name (a string), and service is the name of a defined network service (a string) or a port number (an integer like 80 or an integer string like "80").
trans-unit.target: El host de argumentos y el service especifican dónde conectarse; host es el nombre del host (una cadena) y service es el nombre de un servicio de red definido (una cadena) o un número de puerto (un número entero como 80 o una cadena entera como "80" ).

trans-unit.source: The arguments min-value and max-value should be numbers standing for the starting and final states of the operation. For instance, an operation that scans a buffer should set these to the results of point-min and point-max correspondingly. max-value should be greater than min-value.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos min-value y max-value deben ser números que representen los estados inicial y final de la operación. Por ejemplo, una operación que escanea un búfer debe establecerlos en los resultados de point-min y point-max correspondientemente. max-value debe ser mayor que min-value .

trans-unit.source: The arguments minibuf and all-frames have the same meanings as in the function next-window (see Cyclic Window Ordering). Note that the all-frames argument does not behave exactly like in get-buffer-window.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos minibuf y all-frames tienen el mismo significado que en la función next-window (ver Orden cíclico de ventanas ). Tenga en cuenta que el argumento de all-frames no se comporta exactamente como en get-buffer-window .

trans-unit.source: The arguments params are specified as keyword/value pairs. All the parameters are optional, but if no parameters are specified, the function will do nothing and return nil.
trans-unit.target: Los params argumentos se especifican como pares de palabra clave / valor. Todos los parámetros son opcionales, pero si no se especifican parámetros, la función no hará nada y devolverá nil .

trans-unit.source: The arguments seconds and millisec let you specify timeout periods. The former specifies a period measured in seconds and the latter specifies one measured in milliseconds. The two time periods thus specified are added together, and accept-process-output returns after that much time, even if there is no subprocess output.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos seconds y millisec permiten especificar períodos de tiempo de espera. El primero especifica un período medido en segundos y el segundo especifica uno medido en milisegundos. Los dos períodos de tiempo así especificados se suman, y accept-process-output retorna después de ese tiempo, incluso si no hay salida de subproceso.

trans-unit.source: The arguments after the protected form are handlers. Each handler lists one or more condition names (which are symbols) to specify which errors it will handle. The error symbol specified when an error is signaled also defines a list of condition names. A handler applies to an error if they have any condition names in common. In the example above, there is one handler, and it specifies one condition name, error, which covers all errors.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos que siguen al formulario protegido son controladores. Cada controlador enumera uno o más nombres de condición (que son símbolos) para especificar qué errores manejará. El símbolo de error especificado cuando se señala un error también define una lista de nombres de condiciones. Un controlador se aplica a un error si tienen algún nombre de condición en común. En el ejemplo anterior, hay un controlador y especifica un nombre de condición, error , que cubre todos los errores.

trans-unit.source: The arguments and the forms in each argument are processed in order, and if a previous form already translates <var>to</var> to some other character, say <var>to-alt</var>, <var>from</var> is also translated to <var>to-alt</var>.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos y las formas en cada argumento se procesan en orden, y si una forma anterior ya se traduce <var>to</var> que algún otro carácter, dicen <var>to-alt</var> , <var>from</var> también se traduce a <var>to-alt</var> .

trans-unit.source: The array (either a string or a vector) is a keyboard macro. The events used so far in the lookup form a complete key, and the array is its binding. See Keyboard Macros, for more information.
trans-unit.target: La matriz (ya sea una cadena o un vector) es una macro de teclado. Los eventos utilizados hasta ahora en la búsqueda forman una clave completa y la matriz es su enlace. Consulte Macros de teclado para obtener más información.

trans-unit.target: El tipo de matriz es un subconjunto del tipo de secuencia,y contiene el tipo de cadena,el tipo de vector,el tipo de bool-vector y el tipo de tabla de caracteres.

The association list describing the buffer-local variable bindings of this buffer, not including the built-in buffer-local bindings that have special slots in the buffer object. (Those slots are omitted from this table.) See Buffer-Local Variables.

The attributes :weight and :width have symbolic values in a range centered around normal. Matches that are more extreme (farther from normal) are somewhat preferred to matches that are less extreme (closer to normal); this is designed to ensure that non-normal faces contrast with normal ones, whenever possible.
The attributes of remote files can be cached for better performance. If they are changed outside of Emacs’s control, the cached values become invalid, and must be reread.

The autoloaded file usually contains other definitions and may require or provide one or more features. If the file is not completely loaded (due to an error in the evaluation of its contents), any function definitions or provide calls that occurred during the load are undone. This is to ensure that the next attempt to call any function autoloading from this file will try again to load the file. If not for this, then some of the functions in the file might be defined by the aborted load, but fail to work properly for the lack of certain subroutines not loaded successfully because they come later in the file.
The average width of the font characters. If this is zero, Emacs uses the value of <var>space-width</var> instead, when it calculates text layout on display.
The background stipple, a bitmap.
The backquote-style pattern is more concise, resembles the structure of expval, and avoids binding ls.

The backtrace buffer is killed automatically when you continue execution.

The backtrace buffer is read-only and uses a special major mode, Debugger mode, in which letters are defined as debugger commands. The usual Emacs editing commands are available; thus, you can switch windows to examine the buffer that was being edited at the time of the error, switch buffers, visit files, or do any other sort of editing. However, the debugger is a recursive editing level (see Recursive Editing) and it is wise to go back to the backtrace buffer and exit the debugger (with the

The backtrace buffer shows you the functions that are executing and their argument values. When a backtrace buffer is created, it shows each stack frame on one, possibly very long, line. (A stack frame is the place where the Lisp interpreter records information about a particular invocation of a function.) The most recently called function will be at the top.

The basic function for creating network connections and network servers is make-network-process. It can do either of those jobs, depending on the arguments you give it.

The basic textual scrolling functions are scroll-up (which scrolls forward) and scroll-down (which scrolls backward). In these function names, “up” and “down” refer to the direction of motion of the buffer text relative to the window. Imagine that the text is written on a long roll of paper and that the scrolling commands move the paper up and down. Thus, if you are looking at the middle of a buffer and repeatedly call scroll-down, you will eventually see the beginning of the buffer.
The basis for symbol-file is the data in the variable load-history.
The behavior can be fixed by making a new parent window when splitting <var>W2</var>. The variable described next allows that to be done.
The behavior is also controlled by alist entries for inhibit-same-window, reusable-frames and inhibit-switch-frame, like display-buffer-reuse-window does.

The behavior of display-buffer is highly customizable. To understand how customizations are used in practice, you may wish to study examples illustrating the order of precedence which display-buffer uses to call action functions (see Precedence of Action Functions). To avoid conflicts between Lisp programs calling display-buffer and user customizations of its behavior, it may make sense to follow a number of guidelines which are sketched in the final part of this section (see The Zen of Buffer Display).
The behavior of fit-frame-to-buffer can be controlled with the help of the two options listed next.
The behavior of parse-partial-sexp is also affected by parse-sexp-lookup-properties (see Syntax Properties).
The behavior of buffer display actions (see Choosing Window) can be further modified by the following user options.
The behavior of child frames deviates from that of top-level frames in a number of other ways as well. Here we sketch a few of them:

The behavior of this function may be altered by the window parameters of window, so long as the variable ignore-window-parameters is nil. If the value of the delete-other-windows window parameter is t, this function ignores all other window parameters. Otherwise, if the value of the delete-other-windows window parameter is a function, that function is called with the argument window, in lieu of the usual action of delete-other-windows. See Window Parameters.

The behavior of this function may be altered by the window parameters of window, so long as the variable ignore-window-parameters is nil. If the value of the delete-window window parameter is t, this function ignores all other window parameters. Otherwise, if the value of the delete-window window parameter is a function, that function is called with the argument window, in lieu of the usual action of delete-window. See Window Parameters.

The behavior of this function may be altered by the window parameters of window, so long as the variable ignore-window-parameters is nil. If the value of the split-window window parameter is t, this function ignores all other window parameters. Otherwise, if the value of the split-window window parameter is a function, that function is called with the arguments window, size, and side, in lieu of the usual action of split-window. Otherwise, this function obeys the window-atom or window-side window parameter, if any. See Window Parameters.

The bitwise operations in Emacs Lisp apply only to integers.

The body of the notification. If <var>body</var> is a string, it specifies the text of the notification message. Use embedded newlines to control how the text is broken into lines. The body text can be up to 255 characters long, and will be truncated if it’s longer. Unlike with D-Bus, the body text should be plain text, with no markup.

The buffer file name indicates which file is visited.

The buffer object for the buffer that has been killed remains in existence as long as anything refers to it, but it is specially marked so that you cannot make it current or display it. Killed buffers retain their identity, however; if you kill two distinct buffers, they remain distinct according to eq although both are dead.

The buffer position of the character clicked on in the text area; or, if the click was outside the text area, the window area where it occurred. It is one of the symbols mode-line, header-line, tab-line, vertical-line, left-margin, right-margin, left-fringe, or right-fringe.

The buffer to associate with the process. The value can be either a buffer or a string that names a buffer. Process output goes at the end of that buffer, unless you specify an output stream or filter function to handle the output. If buffer is not given, the process buffer’s name is taken from the value of the :name keyword.
The buffer which its text is generated in.

The buffer will only auto-revert if it is marked unmodified. Hence, you will have to make sure that various functions mark the buffer modified if and only if either the buffer contains information that might be lost by reverting, or there is reason to believe that the user might be inconvenienced by auto-reverting, because he is actively working on the buffer. The user can always override this by manually adjusting the modified status of the buffer. To support this, calling the revert-buffer-function on a buffer that is marked unmodified should always keep the buffer marked unmodified.
The buffer’s value of point, as of the last time a redisplay completed in this window.
The buffer-local value of <var>variable</var> starts out as the same value <var>variable</var> previously had. If <var>variable</var> was void, it remains void.
The buffer-local value of this variable holds the symbol for the current major mode. Its default value holds the default major mode for new buffers. The standard default value is fundamental-mode.

The buffer-local variable enable-multibyte-characters is non-nil in multibyte buffers, and nil in unibyte ones. The mode line also indicates whether a buffer is multibyte or not. With a graphical display, in a multibyte buffer, the portion of the mode line that indicates the character set has a tooltip that (amongst other things) says that the buffer is multibyte. In a unibyte buffer, the character set indicator is absent. Thus, in a unibyte buffer (when using a graphical display) there is normally nothing before the indication of the visited file’s end-of-line convention (colon, backslash, etc.), unless you are using an input method.

The buffer-predicate function for this frame. The function other-buffer uses this predicate (from the selected frame) to decide which buffers it should consider, if the predicate is not nil. It calls the predicate with one argument, a buffer, once for each buffer; if the predicate returns a non-nil value, it considers that buffer.
The built-in function indirect-function provides an easy way to perform symbol function indirection explicitly.

The bulk of grok/pcase is a single clause of a pcase form, the pattern on lines 1-8, the (single) body form on line 9. The pattern is or, which tries to match in turn its argument sub-patterns, first and (lines 2-7), then let (line 8), until one of them succeeds.
The button type. See Button Types.
The button’s keymap, defining bindings active within the button region. By default this is the usual button region keymap, stored in the variable button-map, which defines

The button-creation functions all take the &rest argument properties, which should be a sequence of property value pairs, specifying properties to add to the button; see Button Properties. In addition, the keyword argument :type may be used to specify a button-type from which to inherit other properties; see Button Types. Any properties not explicitly specified during creation will be inherited from the button’s type (if the type defines such a property).

The byte compiler uses the dynamic function loading feature if the variable byte-compile-dynamic is non-nil at compilation time. Do not set this variable globally, since dynamic loading is desirable only for certain files. Instead, enable the feature for specific source files with file-local variable bindings. For example, you could do it by writing this text in the source file’s first line:
The byte position corresponding to window_end_pos.

The byte-code interpreter is implemented as a simple stack machine. It pushes values onto a stack of its own, then pops them off to use them in calculations whose results are themselves pushed back on the stack. When a byte-code function returns, it pops a value off the stack and returns it as the value of the function.
The call to func must be in the then-form of the if, and func must appear quoted in the call to fboundp. (This feature operates for cond as well.)

The canonical way to specify the size of a frame from within Emacs is by specifying its text size—a tuple of the width and height of the frame’s text area (see Frame Layout). It can be measured either in pixels or in terms of the frame’s canonical character size (see Frame Font).
The canonicalize table maps all of a set of case-related characters into a particular member of that set.

The case change commands described here work on text in the current buffer. See Case Conversion, for case conversion functions that work on strings and characters. See Case Tables, for how to customize which characters are upper or lower case and how to convert them.

The category table is actually a char-table (see Char-Tables). The element of the category table at index c is a category set—a bool-vector—that indicates which categories character c belongs to. In this category set, if the element at index cat is t, that means category cat is a member of the set, and that character c belongs to category cat.

The char-table has one extra slot, which determines how to display any character that cannot be displayed with any available font, or cannot be encoded by the terminal’s coding system. Its value should be one of the above display methods, except zero-width or a cons cell.

The coding system raw-text is special in that it prevents character code conversion, and causes the buffer visited with this coding system to be a unibyte buffer. For historical reasons, you can save both unibyte and multibyte text with this coding system. When you use raw-text to encode multibyte text, it does perform one character code conversion: it converts eight-bit characters to their single-byte external representation. raw-text does not specify the end-of-line conversion, allowing that to be determined as usual by the data, and has the usual three variants which specify the end-of-line conversion.

The coding system utf-8-emacs specifies that the data is represented in the internal Emacs encoding (see Text Representations). This is like raw-text in that no code conversion happens, but different in that the result is multibyte data. The name emacs-internal is an alias for utf-8-emacs-unix (so it forces no conversion of end-of-line, unlike utf-8-emacs, which can decode all 3 kinds of end-of-line conventions).
The color for the border of the frame. It is equivalent to the :background attribute of the border face.
The color for the cursor that shows point. It is equivalent to the :background attribute of the cursor face.
The color for the mouse pointer. It is equivalent to the :background attribute of the mouse face.
The color of lines drawn, and outlines around solid shapes.
The color to use for the background of characters. It is equivalent to the :background attribute of the default face.
The color to use for the image of a character. It is equivalent to the :foreground attribute of the default face.
The color used for solid shapes.
The color values are returned for frame’s display. If frame is omitted or nil, the information is returned for the selected frame’s display. If the frame cannot display colors, the value is nil.
The column at which to fill warnings.
The column functions convert between a character position (counting characters from the beginning of the buffer) and a column position (counting screen characters from the beginning of a line).
The column number currently displayed in this window’s mode line, or -1 if column numbers are not being displayed.
The column to be used for top-level constructs. This replaces the default value of the top-level column used by the sub-mode, usually zero.

The combination limit is meaningful only for an internal window. If it is nil, then Emacs is allowed to automatically delete window, in response to a window deletion, in order to group the child windows of window with its sibling windows to form a new window combination. If the combination limit is t, the child windows of window are never automatically recombined with its siblings.
