The command eval-region updates load-history, but does so by adding the symbols defined to the element for the file being visited, rather than replacing that element. See Eval.

trans-unit.source: The command <var>fname</var> is defined to handle a few events itself, by scrolling the display of <var>help-text</var>. When <var>fname</var> reads one of those special events, it does the scrolling and then reads another event. When it reads an event that is not one of those few, and which has a binding in <var>help-map</var>, it executes that key’s binding and then returns.
trans-unit.target: El comando <var>fname</var> está definido para manejar algunos eventos por sí mismo, desplazando la pantalla de <var>help-text</var> de ayuda . Cuando <var>fname</var> lee uno de esos eventos especiales, realiza el desplazamiento y luego lee otro evento. Cuando lee un evento que no es uno de esos pocos, y que tiene un enlace en <var>help-map</var> , ejecuta el enlace de esa clave y luego regresa.

trans-unit.source: The command bindings of input events are recorded in data structures called keymaps. Each entry in a keymap associates (or binds) an individual event type, either to another keymap or to a command. When an event type is bound to a keymap, that keymap is used to look up the next input event; this continues until a command is found. The whole process is called key lookup.
trans-unit.target: Los enlaces de comando de los eventos de entrada se registran en estructuras de datos llamadas mapas de teclas . Cada entrada en un mapa de teclas asocia (o vincula ) un tipo de evento individual, ya sea a otro mapa de teclas oa un comando. Cuando un tipo de evento está vinculado a un mapa de teclas, ese mapa de teclas se usa para buscar el siguiente evento de entrada; esto continúa hasta que se encuentra un comando. Todo el proceso se llama búsqueda de claves .

trans-unit.source: The command does not set this-command to kill-region, so a subsequent kill command does not append to the same kill ring entry.
trans-unit.target: El comando no establece this-command en kill-region , por lo que un comando kill posterior no se agrega a la misma entrada del kill ring.

trans-unit.source: The command loop reads input a key sequence at a time, by calling read-key-sequence. Lisp programs can also call this function; for example, describe-key uses it to read the key to describe.

trans-unit.source: The command loop runs this soon after post-command-hook (q.v.).
trans-unit.target: El ciclo de comando se ejecuta poco después de post-command-hook (qv).

trans-unit.source: The command loop sets this variable just before running a command, and copies its value into last-command when the command finishes (unless the command specified a prefix argument for the following command).

trans-unit.source: The command loop sets this variable to nil before each command, so if a command sets it, the effect applies only to that command.
trans-unit.target: El ciclo de comando establece esta variable en nil antes de cada comando, por lo que si un comando la establece, el efecto se aplica solo a ese comando.

trans-unit.source: The command named mode first performs the standard actions such as setting the variable named mode and then executes the body forms, if any. It then runs the mode hook variable mode-hook and finishes by evaluating any form in :after-hook.

trans-unit.source: The command-line with which the process was invoked. This is a string in which individual command-line arguments are separated by blanks; whitespace characters that are embedded in the arguments are quoted as appropriate for the system’s shell: escaped by backslash characters on GNU and Unix, and enclosed in double quote characters on Windows. Thus, this command-line string can be directly used in primitives such as shell-command.
trans-unit.target: La línea de comandos con la que se invocó el proceso. Esta es una cadena en la que los argumentos individuales de la línea de comandos están separados por espacios en blanco; Los caracteres de espacio en blanco que están incrustados en los argumentos se citan según corresponda para el shell del sistema: con caracteres de escape de barra invertida en GNU y Unix, y encerrados entre comillas dobles en Windows. Por lo tanto, esta cadena de línea de comandos se puede usar directamente en primitivas como shell-command .

trans-unit.source: The commands available during recursive editing are the same ones available in the top-level editing loop and defined in the keymaps. Only a few special commands exit the recursive editing level; the others return to the recursive editing level when they finish. (The special commands for exiting are always available, but they do nothing when recursive editing is not in progress.)
trans-unit.target: Los comandos disponibles durante la edicin recursiva son los mismos que estn disponibles en el bucle de edicin de nivel superior y definidos en los mapas de teclas.Slo unos pocos comandos especiales salen del nivel de edicin recursiva;los dems vuelven al nivel de edicin recursiva cuando terminan.(Los comandos especiales de salida siempre estn disponibles,pero no hacen nada cuando la edicin recursiva no est en progreso).

trans-unit.source: The commands described below can filter the killed text before they save it in the kill ring. They call filter-buffer-substring (see Buffer Contents) to perform the filtering. By default, there’s no filtering, but major and minor modes and hook functions can set up filtering, so that text saved in the kill ring is different from what was in the buffer.
trans-unit.target: Los comandos que se describen a continuación pueden filtrar el texto eliminado antes de guardarlo en el círculo de muerte. Llaman a filter-buffer-substring (ver Contenido del búfer ) para realizar el filtrado. De forma predeterminada, no hay filtrado, pero los modos mayores y menores y las funciones de enlace pueden configurar el filtrado, de modo que el texto guardado en el kill ring sea diferente del que estaba en el búfer.

trans-unit.source: The comment lines show that fac was called 6 times. The first if statement returned 5 times with the same result each time; the same is true of the condition on the second if. The recursive call of fac did not return at all.

trans-unit.source: The communication type and the process filter and sentinel are inherited from those of the server. The server never directly uses its filter and sentinel; their sole purpose is to initialize connections made to the server.

trans-unit.source: The comparison function predicate must give reliable results for any given pair of arguments, at least within a single call to sort. It must be antisymmetric; that is, if a is less than b, b must not be less than a. It must be transitive—that is, if a is less than b, and b is less than c, then a must be less than c. If you use a comparison function which does not meet these requirements, the result of sort is unpredictable.
trans-unit.target: El predicate función de comparación debe dar resultados confiables para cualquier par de argumentos dado, al menos dentro de una sola llamada a sort . Debe ser antisimétrico ; es decir, si a es menor que b , b no debe ser menor que a . Debe ser transitiva , es decir, si a es menor que b , y b es menor que c , entonces a debe ser menor que c . Si usa una función de comparación que no cumple estos requisitos, el resultado de la sort es impredecible.

trans-unit.source: The compiler ignores the provide, then processes the require by loading the file in question. Loading the file does execute the provide call, so the subsequent require call does nothing when the file is loaded.
trans-unit.target: El compilador ignora el provide , luego procesa el require cargando el archivo en cuestión. La carga del archivo ejecuta la llamada provide , por lo que la siguiente llamada require no hace nada cuando se carga el archivo.

trans-unit.source: The complexities stem from the modifier bits that keyboard input characters can include. Aside from the Meta modifier, none of these modifier bits can be included in a string, and the Meta modifier is allowed only in special cases.
trans-unit.target: Las complejidades provienen de los bits modificadores que pueden incluir los caracteres de entrada del teclado.Aparte del modificador Meta,ninguno de estos bits modificadores puede ser incluido en una cadena,y el modificador Meta slo se permite en casos especiales.

trans-unit.source: The concept of raising and lowering frames also applies to text terminal frames. On each text terminal, only the top frame is displayed at any one time.
trans-unit.target: El concepto de subir y bajar marcos tambin se aplica a los marcos terminales de texto.En cada terminal de texto,slo se muestra el marco superior en un momento dado.

trans-unit.source: The concept of visibility is strongly related to that of (un-)mapped frames. A frame (or, more precisely, its window-system window) is and becomes mapped when it is displayed for the first time and whenever it changes its state of visibility from iconified or invisible to visible. Conversely, a frame is and becomes unmapped whenever it changes its status from visible to iconified or invisible.
trans-unit.target: El concepto de visibilidad está fuertemente relacionado con el de marcos (no) mapeados. Un marco (o, más precisamente, su ventana de sistema de ventanas) es y se mapea cuando se muestra por primera vez y siempre que cambia su estado de visibilidad de iconified o invisible a visible . Por el contrario, un marco no está mapeado cada vez que cambia su estado de visible a iconified o invisible .

trans-unit.source: The concise expression of a predicate is known as a pattern. When the predicate, called on the value of the first arg, returns non-nil, we say that “the pattern matches the value” (or sometimes “the value matches the pattern”).
trans-unit.target: La expresión concisa de un predicado se conoce como patrón . Cuando el predicado, llamado sobre el valor del primer argumento, devuelve un valor distinto de nil , decimos que “el patrón coincide con el valor” (oa veces “el valor coincide con el patrón”).

trans-unit.source: The connection’s local address is set up according to the port number used for the connection.
trans-unit.target: La dirección local de la conexión se configura según el número de puerto utilizado para la conexión.

trans-unit.source: The connection’s process contact information is set according to the client’s addressing information (typically an IP address and a port number). This information is associated with the process-contact keywords :host, :service, :remote.
trans-unit.target: La información de contacto del proceso de la conexión se establece de acuerdo con la información de direccionamiento del cliente (generalmente una dirección IP y un número de puerto). Esta información está asociada con los process-contact palabras clave :host , :service , :remote .

trans-unit.source: The constant display-buffer-fallback-action.
trans-unit.target: La constante display-buffer-fallback-action .

trans-unit.source: The construct ‘
trans-unit.target: El constructo '

trans-unit.source: The contents of a buffer are much like a string, but buffers are not used like strings in Emacs Lisp, and the available operations are different. For example, you can insert text efficiently into an existing buffer, altering the buffer’s contents, whereas inserting text into a string requires concatenating substrings, and the result is an entirely new string object.
trans-unit.target: El contenido de un búfer es muy parecido a una cadena, pero los búferes no se usan como cadenas en Emacs Lisp y las operaciones disponibles son diferentes. Por ejemplo, puede insertar texto de manera eficiente en un búfer existente, alterando el contenido del búfer, mientras que insertar texto en una cadena requiere concatenar subcadenas, y el resultado es un objeto de cadena completamente nuevo.

trans-unit.source: The contents of a documentation string should follow certain conventions. In particular, its first line should be a complete sentence (or two complete sentences) that briefly describes what the function or variable does. See Documentation Tips, for how to write good documentation strings.
trans-unit.target: El contenido de una cadena de documentación debe seguir ciertas convenciones. En particular, su primera línea debe ser una oración completa (o dos oraciones completas) que describa brevemente lo que hace la función o variable. Consulte Consejos de documentación para saber cómo escribir buenas cadenas de documentación.

trans-unit.source: The contents of each mode line are specified by the buffer-local variable mode-line-format (see Mode Line Top). This variable holds a mode line construct: a template that controls what is displayed on the buffer’s mode line. The value of header-line-format specifies the buffer’s header line in the same way. All windows for the same buffer use the same mode-line-format and header-line-format unless a mode-line-format or header-line-format parameter has been specified for that window (see Window Parameters).
trans-unit.target: El contenido de cada línea de modo se especifica mediante la variable local de búfer mode-line-format (ver Línea de modo superior ). Esta variable contiene una construcción de línea de modo : una plantilla que controla lo que se muestra en la línea de modo del búfer. El valor de header-line-format especifica la línea de encabezado del búfer de la misma manera. Todas las ventanas para el mismo tampón utilizan el mismo mode-line-format y de header-line-format a menos que un mode-line-format o de header-line-format parámetro se ha especificado para esa ventana (véase la ventana Parámetros ).

trans-unit.source: The contents of the function cell are also called the symbol’s function definition. The procedure of using a symbol’s function definition in place of the symbol is called symbol function indirection; see Function Indirection. If you have not given a symbol a function definition, its function cell is said to be void, and it cannot be used as a function.
trans-unit.target: El contenido de la celda de función también se denomina definición de función del símbolo . El procedimiento de utilizar la definición de función de un símbolo en lugar del símbolo se denomina indirección de función de símbolo ; consulte Indirección de funciones . Si no le ha dado a un símbolo una definición de función, se dice que su celda de función es nula y no se puede usar como una función.

trans-unit.source: The control modifier.
trans-unit.target: El modificador de control.

trans-unit.source: The convenient way to track the mouse is to ask for events to represent mouse motion. Then you can wait for motion by waiting for an event. In addition, you can easily handle any other sorts of events that may occur. That is useful, because normally you don’t want to track the mouse forever—only until some other event, such as the release of a button.
trans-unit.target: La forma conveniente de realizar un seguimiento del mouse es solicitar eventos que representen el movimiento del mouse. Luego, puede esperar el movimiento esperando un evento. Además, puede manejar fácilmente cualquier otro tipo de eventos que puedan ocurrir. Eso es útil, porque normalmente no desea seguir el mouse para siempre, solo hasta que ocurra algún otro evento, como la liberación de un botón.

trans-unit.source: The coordinate arguments frompos and topos are cons cells of the form (hpos . vpos).
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos de coordenadas frompos y topos son celdas de cons de la forma (hpos . vpos) .

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the divider separating <var>window</var> from a window beneath.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas están en el divisor que separa la <var>window</var> de una ventana debajo.

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the divider separating <var>window</var> from a window on the right.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas están en el divisor que separa la <var>window</var> de una ventana a la derecha.

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the header line of <var>window</var>.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas están en la línea de encabezado de la <var>window</var> .

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the left or right fringe of the window.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas estn en la franja izquierda o derecha de la ventana.

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the left or right margin of the window.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas estn en el margen izquierdo o derecho de la ventana.

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the mode line of <var>window</var>.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas están en la línea de modo de la <var>window</var> .

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the tab line of <var>window</var>.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas están en la línea de pestañas de la <var>window</var> .

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are in the vertical line between <var>window</var> and its neighbor to the right. This value occurs only if the window doesn’t have a scroll bar; positions in a scroll bar are considered outside the window for these purposes.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas están en la línea vertical entre la <var>window</var> y su vecino a la derecha. Este valor ocurre solo si la ventana no tiene una barra de desplazamiento; las posiciones en una barra de desplazamiento se consideran fuera de la ventana para estos fines.

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are inside <var>window</var>. The numbers <var>relx</var> and <var>rely</var> are the equivalent window-relative coordinates for the specified position, counting from 0 at the top left corner of the window.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas están dentro de la <var>window</var> . Los números <var>relx</var> y <var>rely</var> son las coordenadas de la ventana, en relación equivalentes respecto a la posición especificada, a contar desde 0 en la esquina superior izquierda de la ventana.

trans-unit.source: The coordinates are not in any part of <var>window</var>.
trans-unit.target: Las coordenadas no están en ninguna parte de la <var>window</var> .

trans-unit.source: The correspondences in a hash table are in no particular order.
trans-unit.target: Las correspondencias en una tabla de hachs no estn en ningn orden particular.

trans-unit.source: The current buffer is restored even in case of an abnormal exit via throw or error (see Nonlocal Exits).
trans-unit.target: El búfer actual se restaura incluso en caso de una salida anormal mediante un throw o un error (consulte Salidas no locales ).

trans-unit.target: El nombre del búfer actual, obtenido con la función buffer-name . Consulte Nombres de búfer .

trans-unit.target: El nmero actual de la columna de puntos,contando desde cero empezando por el margen izquierdo de la ventana.

trans-unit.source: The current file name in byte-compiled files (see Docs and Compilation). This is not meant to be used in Emacs Lisp source files.
trans-unit.target: El nombre del archivo actual en archivos compilados por bytes (consulte Documentos y compilación ). Esto no está destinado a ser utilizado en archivos fuente de Emacs Lisp.

trans-unit.source: The current value of this variable is used to rebind help-form locally inside the minibuffer (see Help Functions).

trans-unit.source: The current working directory of the subprocess is set to the current buffer’s value of default-directory if that is local (as determined by unhandled-file-name-directory), or

trans-unit.source: The current working directory of the subprocess is set to the current buffer’s value of default-directory if that is local (as determined by unhandled-file-name-directory), or "~" otherwise. If you want to run a process in a remote directory use process-file.
trans-unit.target: El directorio de trabajo actual del subproceso se establece en el valor del búfer actual de default-directory si es local (según lo determinado por unhandled-file-name-directory ), o "~" en caso contrario. Si desea ejecutar un proceso en un directorio remoto, use process-file .

trans-unit.source: The customization buffer shows all legitimate values using their read syntax, and the user edits them textually.
trans-unit.target: La memoria intermedia de personalizacin muestra todos los valores legtimos utilizando su sintaxis de lectura,y el usuario los edita textualmente.

trans-unit.source: The customization declarations that we will describe in the next few sections—defcustom, defgroup, etc.—all accept keyword arguments (see Constant Variables) for specifying various information. This section describes keywords that apply to all types of customization declarations.
trans-unit.target: Las declaraciones de personalización que describiremos en las próximas secciones ( defcustom , defgroup , etc.) aceptan argumentos de palabras clave (consulte Variables constantes ) para especificar información diversa. Esta sección describe las palabras clave que se aplican a todos los tipos de declaraciones de personalización.

trans-unit.source: The data as a byte array.
trans-unit.target: Los datos como una matriz de bytes.

trans-unit.source: The datagram connection doesn’t have to talk with the same remote peer all the time. It has a remote peer address which specifies where to send datagrams to. Each time an incoming datagram is passed to the filter function, the peer address is set to the address that datagram came from; that way, if the filter function sends a datagram, it will go back to that place. You can specify the remote peer address when you create the datagram connection using the :remote keyword. You can change it later on by calling set-process-datagram-address.
trans-unit.target: La conexión de datagramas no tiene que hablar con el mismo par remoto todo el tiempo. Tiene una dirección de par remoto que especifica a dónde enviar los datagramas. Cada vez que se pasa un datagrama entrante a la función de filtro, la dirección del par se establece en la dirección de la que proviene el datagrama; de esa manera, si la función de filtro envía un datagrama, volverá a ese lugar. Puede especificar la dirección del par remoto cuando crea la conexión de datagrama usando la palabra clave :remote . Puede cambiarlo más adelante llamando a set-process-datagram-address .

trans-unit.source: The day of the month, as an integer between 1 and 31.
trans-unit.target: El da del mes,como un nmero entero entre 1 y 31.

trans-unit.source: The day of week, as an integer between 0 and 6, where 0 stands for Sunday.
trans-unit.target: El da de la semana,como un nmero entero entre 0 y 6,donde el 0 representa el domingo.

trans-unit.source: The debugger buffer (in Debugger mode) provides special commands in addition to the usual Emacs commands and to the Backtrace mode commands described in the previous section. The most important use of debugger commands is for stepping through code, so that you can see how control flows. The debugger can step through the control structures of an interpreted function, but cannot do so in a byte-compiled function. If you would like to step through a byte-compiled function, replace it with an interpreted definition of the same function. (To do this, visit the source for the function and type
trans-unit.target: La memoria intermedia del depurador (en el modo Debugger)proporciona comandos especiales adems de los comandos habituales de Emacs y de los comandos del modo Backtrace descritos en la seccin anterior.El uso ms importante de los comandos del depurador es para pasar a travs del cdigo,para que puedas ver cmo fluye el control.El depurador puede atravesar las estructuras de control de una funcin interpretada,pero no puede hacerlo en una funcin compilada en bytes.Si desea pasar por una funcin compilada en bytes,sustityala por una definicin interpretada de la misma funcin.(Para ello,visite la fuente de la funcin y escriba

trans-unit.source: The debugger itself must be run byte-compiled, since it makes assumptions about the state of the Lisp interpreter. These assumptions are false if the debugger is running interpreted.
trans-unit.target: El propio depurador debe ser ejecutado por byte-compilado,ya que hace suposiciones sobre el estado del intrprete de Lisp.Estas suposiciones son falsas si el depurador se ejecuta interpretado.

trans-unit.target: El formulario de declaracin

trans-unit.source: The decoding functions ignore newline characters in the encoded text.
trans-unit.target: Las funciones de decodificacin ignoran los caracteres de nueva lnea en el texto codificado.

trans-unit.source: The default behavior is abandoned as soon as the user customizes one of these thresholds or manually changes the frame’s layout. The default behavior is also abandoned when calling display-buffer with a non-nilaction argument or the user customizes one of the options mentioned in the previous subsections. Mastering display-buffer soon may become a frustrating experience due to the plethora of applicable display actions and the resulting frame layouts.
trans-unit.target: El comportamiento predeterminado se abandona tan pronto como el usuario personaliza uno de estos umbrales o cambia manualmente el diseño del marco. El comportamiento predeterminado también se abandona cuando se llama a display-buffer con un argumento de action no es nil o el usuario personaliza una de las opciones mencionadas en las subsecciones anteriores. Dominar display-buffer pronto puede convertirse en una experiencia frustrante debido a la gran cantidad de acciones de visualización aplicables y los diseños de cuadros resultantes.

trans-unit.source: The default directory for temporary files is controlled by the variable temporary-file-directory. This variable gives the user a uniform way to specify the directory for all temporary files. Some programs use small-temporary-file-directory instead, if that is non-nil. To use it, you should expand the prefix against the proper directory before calling make-temp-file.
trans-unit.target: El directorio predeterminado para archivos temporales está controlado por la variable temporary-file-directory . Esta variable le da al usuario una forma uniforme de especificar el directorio para todos los archivos temporales. En su lugar, algunos programas utilizan small-temporary-file-directory , si no es nil . Para usarlo, debe expandir el prefijo contra el directorio adecuado antes de llamar a make-temp-file .

trans-unit.source: The default expansion function returns the abbrev symbol if it did expansion, and nil otherwise. If the abbrev symbol has a hook function that is a symbol whose no-self-insert property is non-nil, and if the hook function returns nil as its value, then the default expansion function returns nil, even though expansion did occur.
trans-unit.target: La función de expansión predeterminada devuelve el símbolo de abreviatura si se expandió, y nil caso contrario. Si el símbolo de abreviaturas tiene una función de enlace que es un símbolo cuya no-self-insert propiedad es no nil , y si la función de enlace vuelve nil como su valor, entonces la función de expansión predeterminada devuelve nil , a pesar de que la expansión se produjo.

trans-unit.source: The default face spec determines face’s appearance when no customizations are in effect (see Customization). If face has already been customized (via Custom themes or via customizations read from the init file), its appearance is determined by the custom face spec(s), which override the default face spec spec. However, if the customizations are subsequently removed, the appearance of face will again be determined by its default face spec.
trans-unit.target: La especificación de cara predeterminada determina la apariencia de la face cuando no hay personalizaciones en vigor (consulte Personalización ). Si face ya se ha personalizado (a través de temas personalizados o mediante personalizaciones leen desde el archivo de inicio), su aparición está determinada por la cara costumbre de especificaciones (s), que anula la cara por defecto spec spec . Sin embargo, si las personalizaciones se eliminan posteriormente, la apariencia de la face volverá a estar determinada por su especificación de cara predeterminada.

trans-unit.source: The default face, whose attributes are all specified. All other faces implicitly inherit from it: any unspecified attribute defaults to the attribute on this face (see Face Attributes).
trans-unit.target: La cara predeterminada, cuyos atributos están todos especificados. Todas las demás caras heredan implícitamente de ella: cualquier atributo no especificado toma como valor predeterminado el atributo de esta cara (consulte Atributos de caras ).

trans-unit.source: The default file permissions have no effect when you save a modified version of an existing file; saving a file preserves its existing permissions.
trans-unit.target: Los permisos de archivo predeterminados no tienen efecto cuando se guarda una versin modificada de un archivo existente;al guardar un archivo se conservan los permisos existentes.

trans-unit.source: The default filter function consults the obsolete wrapper hook filter-buffer-substring-functions (see the documentation string of the macro with-wrapper-hook for the details about this obsolete facility), and the obsolete variable buffer-substring-filters. If both of these are nil, it returns the unaltered text from the buffer, i.e., what buffer-substring would return.
trans-unit.target: La función de filtro predeterminada consulta el gancho contenedor obsoleto filter-buffer-substring-functions (consulte la cadena de documentación de la macro with-wrapper-hook para obtener detalles sobre esta función obsoleta) y la variable obsoleta buffer-substring-filters . Si ambos son nil , devuelve el texto inalterado del búfer, es decir, qué buffer-substring devolvería.

trans-unit.source: The default filter function uses this marker to decide where to insert process output, and updates it to point after the inserted text. That is why successive batches of output are inserted consecutively.
trans-unit.target: La funcin de filtro predeterminado utiliza este marcador para decidir dnde insertar la salida del proceso,y lo actualiza para que apunte despus del texto insertado.Por eso se insertan sucesivos lotes de salida de forma consecutiva.

trans-unit.target: El valor predeterminado para weak es nil , por lo que todas las claves y valores a los que se hace referencia en la tabla hash se conservan de la recolección de basura.

trans-unit.target: El valor predeterminado es nil . Otros valores están reservados para uso futuro. Una operación de división específica puede ignorar el valor de esta variable si se ve afectada por un valor no nil de window-combination-limit .

trans-unit.source: The default is window-size. Other values are reserved for future use.
trans-unit.target: El valor predeterminado es window-size . Otros valores están reservados para uso futuro.

trans-unit.source: The default is to call iconify-frame (see Visibility of Frames). Alternatively, you may specify either delete-frame (see Deleting Frames) to remove the frame from its display, make-frame-invisible to make the frame invisible, ignore to leave the frame unchanged, or any other function that can take a frame as its sole argument.
trans-unit.target: El valor predeterminado es llamar a iconify-frame (consulte Visibilidad de marcos ). Alternativamente, puede especificar delete-frame (ver Eliminación de marcos ) para eliminar el marco de su visualización, make-frame-invisible para hacer que el marco sea invisible, ignore para dejar el marco sin cambios, o cualquier otra función que pueda tomar un marco como su único argumento.

trans-unit.source: The default size is 65.

trans-unit.source: The default stroke color on any lines created.
trans-unit.target: El color de trazo por defecto en cualquier lnea creada.

trans-unit.source: The default time zone is determined by the TZ environment variable. See System Environment. For example, you can tell Emacs to default to Universal Time with (setenv "TZ" "UTC0"). If TZ is not in the environment, Emacs uses system wall clock time, which is a platform-dependent default time zone.
trans-unit.target: La zona horaria predeterminada está determinada por la variable de entorno TZ . Consulte Entorno del sistema . Por ejemplo, puede decirle a Emacs que establezca por defecto el tiempo universal con (setenv "TZ" "UTC0") . Si TZ no está en el entorno, Emacs usa la hora del reloj de pared del sistema, que es una zona horaria predeterminada dependiente de la plataforma.

trans-unit.source: The default tool bar is defined so that items specific to editing do not appear for major modes whose command symbol has a mode-class property of special (see Major Mode Conventions). Major modes may add items to the global bar by binding [tool-bar foo] in their local map. It makes sense for some major modes to replace the default tool bar items completely, since not many can be accommodated conveniently, and the default bindings make this easy by using an indirection through tool-bar-map.
The default value nil should be used when your window manager follows a “click-to-focus” policy where you have to click the mouse inside of a frame in order for that frame to gain focus.
The default value for fill-column is 70.
The default value is 1.5.
The default value is 1600. Entry to the Lisp debugger increases the value, if there is little room left, to make sure the debugger itself has room to execute.

The default value is '(tab-bar-lines tool-bar-lines) for Lucid, Motif and MS-Windows (which means that adding/removing a tool or tab bar there does not change the outer frame height), '(tab-bar-lines) on all other window systems including GTK+ (which means that changing any of the parameters listed above with the exception of tab-bar-lines may change the size of the outer frame), and t otherwise (which means the outer frame size never changes implicitly when there’s no window system support).
The default value is nil, i.e., the prefix-discarding feature is disabled. This is because discarding prefixes often leads to confusing names for options and faces.
The default value is normal-backup-enable-predicate, which checks for files in temporary-file-directory and small-temporary-file-directory.
The default value is step. This variable can be set interactively with

The default value is determined in a reasonable way for your operating system; it is based on the TMPDIR, TMP and TEMP environment variables, with a fall-back to a system-dependent name if none of these variables is defined.
The default value is seen in buffers that don’t have their own buffer-local values.
The default value is the function that clears the message displayed in an active minibuffer.

The default value is the function that displays the message at the end of the minibuffer when the minibuffer is active. However, if the text shown in the active minibuffer has the minibuffer-message text property (see Special Properties) on some character, the message will be displayed before the first character having that property.
The default value is zero, which means that conservative scrolling never happens.
The default value matches whitespace with certain punctuation characters intermingled.

The default value of auto-hscroll-mode is t; setting it to current-line activates a variant of automatic horizontal scrolling whereby only the line showing the cursor is horizontally scrolled to make point visible, the rest of the window is left either unscrolled, or at the minimum scroll amount set by scroll-left and scroll-right, see below.

The default value of bidi-display-reordering controls the reordering of strings which are not directly supplied by a buffer, including the text displayed in mode lines (see Mode Line Format) and header lines (see Header Lines).

The default value of imenu-create-index-function is imenu-default-create-index-function. This function calls the value of imenu-prev-index-position-function and the value of imenu-extract-index-name-function to produce the index alist. However, if either of these two variables is nil, the default function uses imenu-generic-expression instead.

The default value of mode-line-format is designed to use the values of other variables such as mode-line-position and mode-line-modes (which in turn incorporates the values of the variables mode-name and minor-mode-alist). Very few modes need to alter mode-line-format itself. For most purposes, it is sufficient to alter some of the variables that mode-line-format either directly or indirectly refers to.
The default value of separators for split-string. Its usual value is "[ \f\t\n\r\v]+".

The default value of this variable is 800. If you set it to a value less than 100, Lisp will reset it to 100 if the given value is reached. Entry to the Lisp debugger increases the value, if there is little room left, to make sure the debugger itself has room to execute.

The default value of this variable is "\\`[ \t]*\\'", which matches only a string of whitespace. The effect of this default is to force the fill prefixes found in one-line paragraphs always to be pure whitespace.

The default value of this variable specifies functions called during redisplay when a window state change has been detected or the window state change flag has been set on at least one frame. The value should be a list of functions that take no argument.
The default width (in pixels) of any lines created.
The default width of the left and right fringes of windows in this frame (see Fringes). If either of these is zero, that effectively removes the corresponding fringe.

The definitions are only available during the macro-expansion of <var>body</var>, and are thus not present during execution of compiled code.
The definitions live in a name space of their own, separate from that of Lisp variables. There is thus no need to attach a suffix like -regexp to names; they cannot collide with anything else.

The descriptor of the arguments. This can either be a list of arguments, as described in Argument List, or an integer encoding the required number of arguments. In the latter case, the value of the descriptor specifies the minimum number of arguments in the bits zero to 6, and the maximum number of arguments in bits 8 to 14. If the argument list uses &rest, then bit 7 is set; otherwise it’s cleared.

The destructive aspect of sort for lists is that it rearranges the cons cells forming sequence by changing CDRs. A nondestructive sort function would create new cons cells to store the elements in their sorted order. If you wish to make a sorted copy without destroying the original, copy it first with copy-sequence and then sort.

The difference between defconst and defvar is mainly a matter of intent, serving to inform human readers of whether the value should ever change. Emacs Lisp does not actually prevent you from changing the value of a variable defined with defconst. One notable difference between the two forms is that defconst unconditionally initializes the variable, whereas defvar initializes it only if it is originally void.

The difference between a directory name and a directory file name is subtle but crucial. When an Emacs variable or function argument is described as being a directory name, a directory file name is not acceptable. When file-name-directory returns a string, that is always a directory name.

The difference from start-process is that this function may invoke a file name handler based on the value of default-directory. This handler ought to run program, perhaps on the local host, perhaps on a remote host that corresponds to default-directory. In the latter case, the local part of default-directory becomes the working directory of the process.

The direct effect of calling provide is to add feature to the front of features if it is not already in that list and call any eval-after-load code waiting for it (see Hooks for Loading). The argument feature must be a symbol. provide returns feature.
The directory for expanding relative file names. This is the value of the buffer-local variable default-directory (see File Name Expansion).

The directory for writing temporary files via make-nearby-temp-file. In case of a remote default-directory, this is a directory for temporary files on that remote host. If such a directory does not exist, or default-directory ought to be located on a mounted file system (see mounted-file-systems), the function returns default-directory. For a non-remote and non-mounted default-directory, the value of the variable temporary-file-directory is returned.
The directory part of a file name, and the rest.

The display routines insist that the position of point be visible when a buffer is displayed. Normally, they select the display-start position according to their internal logic (and scroll the window if necessary) to make point visible. However, if you specify the start position with this function using nil for noforce, it means you want display to start at position even if that would put the location of point off the screen. If this does place point off screen, the display routines attempt to move point to the left margin on the middle line in the window.
The display table also has six extra slots which serve special purposes. Here is a table of their meanings; nil in any slot means to use the default for that slot, as stated below.

The distinction between the values t and auto-raise is not needed for “normal” frames because the window manager usually takes care of raising them. It is useful to automatically raise child frames via mouse-autoselect-window (see Mouse Window Auto-selection).
The documentation for the variable, as a C comment. See Documentation Basics, for more details.

The easiest way to construct a keymap with a prompt string is to specify the string as an argument when you call make-keymap, make-sparse-keymap (see Creating Keymaps), or define-prefix-command (see Definition of define-prefix-command). If you do not want the keymap to operate as a menu, don’t specify a prompt string for it.

The easiest way to insert and manipulate links is to use the button package. See Buttons. In this section, we will explain how to manually set up clickable text in a buffer, using text properties. For simplicity, we will refer to the clickable text as a link.
The easiest way to make a string with text properties is with propertize:

The easiest way to mark a function as obsolete is to put a (declare (obsolete …)) form in the function’s defun definition. See Declare Form. Alternatively, you can use the make-obsolete function, described below.

The easiest way to write a major mode is to use the macro define-derived-mode, which sets up the new mode as a variant of an existing major mode. See Derived Modes. We recommend using define-derived-mode even if the new mode is not an obvious derivative of another mode, as it automatically enforces many coding conventions for you. See Basic Major Modes, for common modes to derive from.

The editor command loop automatically calls undo-boundary just before executing each key sequence, so that each undo normally undoes the effects of one command. A few exceptional commands are amalgamating: these commands generally cause small changes to buffers, so with these a boundary is inserted only every 20th command, allowing the changes to be undone as a group. By default, the commands self-insert-command, which produces self-inserting input characters (see Commands for Insertion), and delete-char, which deletes characters (see Deletion), are amalgamating. Where a command affects the contents of several buffers, as may happen, for example, when a function on the post-command-hook affects a buffer other than the current-buffer, then undo-boundary will be called in each of the affected buffers.

The editor command loop reads key sequences using the function read-key-sequence, which uses read-event. These and other functions for event input are also available for use in Lisp programs. See also momentary-string-display in Temporary Displays, and sit-for in Waiting. See Terminal Input, for functions and variables for controlling terminal input modes and debugging terminal input.

The editor command loop sets several Lisp variables to keep status records for itself and for commands that are run. With the exception of this-command and last-command it’s generally a bad idea to change any of these variables in a Lisp program.

The effect is that this keymap inherits all the bindings of <var>parent-keymap</var>, whatever they may be at the time a key is looked up, but can add to them or override them with <var>elements</var>.

The effect of debug here is only to prevent condition-case from suppressing the call to the debugger. Any given error will invoke the debugger only if debug-on-error and the other usual filtering mechanisms say it should. See Error Debugging.

The effective user ID of the user who invoked the process. The corresponding value is a number. If the process was invoked by the same user who runs the current Emacs session, the value is identical to what user-uid returns (see User Identification).

The element position is a list describing the position of the event, in the same format as used in a mouse-click event (see Click Events), and files is the list of file names that were dragged and dropped. The usual way to handle this event is by visiting these files.

The elements left-fringe, right-fringe, left-margin, right-margin, scroll-bar, and text specify the width of the corresponding area of the window. When the window displays line numbers (see Size of Displayed Text), the width of the text area is decreased by the screen space taken by the line-number display.

trans-unit.source: The first number arguments of the function are distinguished arguments; the rest are considered the body of the expression. A line in the expression is indented according to whether the first argument on it is distinguished or not. If the argument is part of the body, the line is indented lisp-body-indent more columns than the open-parenthesis starting the containing expression. If the argument is distinguished and is either the first or second argument, it is indented twice that many extra columns. If the argument is distinguished and not the first or second argument, the line uses the standard pattern.
trans-unit.target: Los primeros argumentos number de la función son argumentos distinguidos ; el resto se considera el cuerpo de la expresión. Una línea en la expresión se sangra según se distinga o no el primer argumento. Si el argumento es parte del cuerpo, la línea tiene sangría lisp-body-indent más columnas que el paréntesis abierto que comienza la expresión contenedora. Si el argumento se distingue y es el primer o el segundo argumento, se sangra el doble de columnas adicionales. Si se distingue el argumento y no el primer o segundo argumento, la línea usa el patrón estándar.

trans-unit.source: The first element of a lambda expression is always the symbol lambda. This indicates that the list represents a function. The reason functions are defined to start with lambda is so that other lists, intended for other uses, will not accidentally be valid as functions.

trans-unit.source: The first element of an array has index zero, the second element has index 1, and so on. This is called zero-origin indexing. For example, an array of four elements has indices 0, 1, 2, and 3.
trans-unit.target: El primer elemento de una matriz tiene índice cero, el segundo elemento tiene índice 1 y así sucesivamente. Esto se denomina indexación de origen cero . Por ejemplo, una matriz de cuatro elementos tiene índices 0, 1, 2 y 3.

trans-unit.source: The first element of an array has index zero, the second element has index 1, and so on. This is called zero-origin indexing. For example, an array of four elements has indices 0, 1, 2, and 3. The largest possible index value is one less than the length of the array. Once an array is created, its length is fixed.
trans-unit.target: El primer elemento de una matriz tiene índice cero, el segundo elemento tiene índice 1 y así sucesivamente. Esto se denomina indexación de origen cero . Por ejemplo, una matriz de cuatro elementos tiene índices 0, 1, 2 y 3. El valor de índice más grande posible es uno menos que la longitud de la matriz. Una vez que se crea una matriz, su longitud es fija.

trans-unit.source: The first element of the quit-restore parameter is one of the symbols window, meaning that the window has been specially created by display-buffer; frame, a separate frame has been created; same, the window has only ever displayed this buffer; or other, the window showed another buffer before. frame and window affect how the window is quit, while same and other affect the redisplay of buffers previously shown in window.
trans-unit.target: El primer elemento del parámetro quit-restore es una de las window símbolos , lo que significa que la ventana ha sido creada especialmente por display-buffer ; frame , se ha creado un marco separado; same , la ventana solo ha mostrado este búfer; u other , la ventana mostró otro búfer antes. frame y la window afectan la forma en que se cierra la ventana, mientras que el same y other afectan la nueva visualización de los búferes que se mostraron anteriormente en la window .

trans-unit.source: The first element, <var>decoding-system</var>, is the coding system to use for decoding (in case <var>operation</var> does decoding), and <var>encoding-system</var> is the coding system for encoding (in case <var>operation</var> does encoding).

trans-unit.source: The first hook function is passed a fun that is equivalent to the default operation of filter-buffer-substring, i.e., it returns the buffer-substring between start and end (processed by any buffer-substring-filters) and optionally deletes the original text from the buffer. In most cases, the hook function will call fun once, and then do its own processing of the result. The next hook function receives a fun equivalent to this, and so on. The actual return value is the result of all the hook functions acting in sequence.
trans-unit.target: La primera función de gancho recibe una fun que es equivalente a la operación predeterminada de filter-buffer-substring , es decir, devuelve la subcadena de búfer entre el start y el end (procesada por cualquier buffer-substring-filters ) y, opcionalmente, elimina el texto original del búfer. En la mayoría de los casos, la función hook llamará a fun una vez y luego hará su propio procesamiento del resultado. La siguiente función de gancho recibe un fun equivalente a esto, y así sucesivamente. El valor de retorno real es el resultado de todas las funciones de gancho que actúan en secuencia.

trans-unit.source: The first step in evaluating a function call is to evaluate the remaining elements of the list from left to right. The results are the actual argument values, one value for each list element. The next step is to call the function with this list of arguments, effectively using the function apply (see Calling Functions). If the function is written in Lisp, the arguments are used to bind the argument variables of the function (see Lambda Expressions); then the forms in the function body are evaluated in order, and the value of the last body form becomes the value of the function call.
trans-unit.target: El primer paso para evaluar una llamada de función es evaluar los elementos restantes de la lista de izquierda a derecha. Los resultados son los valores reales de los argumentos, un valor para cada elemento de la lista. El siguiente paso es llamar a la función con esta lista de argumentos, usando efectivamente la función apply (ver Llamar a funciones ). Si la función está escrita en Lisp, los argumentos se utilizan para vincular las variables de argumento de la función (consulte Expresiones Lambda ); luego, los formularios en el cuerpo de la función se evalúan en orden y el valor del último formulario del cuerpo se convierte en el valor de la llamada a la función.

trans-unit.source: The first step in evaluating a nonempty list is to examine its first element. This element alone determines what kind of form the list is and how the rest of the list is to be processed. The first element is not evaluated, as it would be in some Lisp dialects such as Scheme.
trans-unit.target: El primer paso para evaluar una lista no vacía es examinar su primer elemento. Este elemento por sí solo determina qué tipo de formulario es la lista y cómo se procesará el resto de la lista. El primer elemento no se evalúa, como lo estaría en algunos dialectos Lisp como Scheme.

trans-unit.source: The first thing the command loop must do is read a key sequence, which is a sequence of input events that translates into a command. It does this by calling the function read-key-sequence. Lisp programs can also call this function (see Key Sequence Input). They can also read input at a lower level with read-key or read-event (see Reading One Event), or discard pending input with discard-input (see Event Input Misc).
trans-unit.target: Lo primero que debe hacer el ciclo de comando es leer una secuencia de teclas, que es una secuencia de eventos de entrada que se traduce en un comando. Lo hace llamando a la función read-key-sequence . Los programas Lisp también pueden llamar a esta función (ver Entrada de secuencia de teclas ). También pueden leer la entrada en un nivel inferior con read-key o read-event (ver Lectura de un evento ), o descartar la entrada pendiente con discard-input (ver Event Input Misc ).

trans-unit.source: The first thing this function does is to activate a minibuffer and display it with <var>prompt</var> (which must be a string) as the prompt. Then the user can edit text in the minibuffer.
trans-unit.target: Lo primero que hace esta función es activar un minibúfer y mostrarlo con un <var>prompt</var> (que debe ser una cadena) como indicador. Luego, el usuario puede editar texto en el minibúfer.

trans-unit.source: The first three clauses use backquote-style patterns. `(add ,x ,y) is a pattern that checks that form is a three-element list starting with the literal symbol add, then extracts the second and third elements and binds them to symbols x and y, respectively. The clause body evaluates x and y and adds the results. Similarly, the call clause implements a function call, and the fn clause implements an anonymous function definition.
trans-unit.target: Las primeras tres cláusulas utilizan patrones de estilo de comillas inversas. `(add ,x ,y) es un patrón que cheques que form a es una lista de tres elementos de partida con el símbolo literal add , a continuación, extrae los elementos segundo y tercero y se une a ellos símbolos x y y , respectivamente. Los evalúa cuerpo cláusula x y y y añade los resultados. De manera similar, la cláusula de call implementa una llamada de función y la cláusula fn implementa una definición de función anónima.

trans-unit.source: The first three sections below should tell you enough about Edebug to start using it.
trans-unit.target: Las tres primeras secciones a continuacin deberan decirte lo suficiente sobre Edebug para empezar a usarlo.

trans-unit.source: The first two arguments, start and end, are the beginning and end of the region to be filled. The third and fourth arguments, justify and citation-regexp, are optional. If justify is non-nil, the paragraphs are justified as well as filled. If citation-regexp is non-nil, it means the function is operating on a mail message and therefore should not fill the header lines. If citation-regexp is a string, it is used as a regular expression; if it matches the beginning of a line, that line is treated as a citation marker.
trans-unit.target: Los dos primeros argumentos, start y end , son el principio y el final de la región que se va a rellenar. Los argumentos tercero y cuarto, justify y citation-regexp , son opcionales. Si justify no es nil , los párrafos se justifican y se completan. Si citation-regexp no es nil , significa que la función está operando en un mensaje de correo y por lo tanto no debe llenar las líneas de encabezado. Si citation-regexp es una cadena, se usa como expresión regular; si coincide con el comienzo de una línea, esa línea se trata como un marcador de cita.

trans-unit.source: The first variant, explicit selective display, was designed for use in a Lisp program: it controls which lines are hidden by altering the text. This kind of hiding is now obsolete and deprecated; instead you should use the invisible property (see Invisible Text) to get the same effect.
trans-unit.target: La primera variante, visualización selectiva explícita, fue diseñada para su uso en un programa Lisp: controla qué líneas están ocultas alterando el texto. Este tipo de ocultación ahora está obsoleto y en desuso; en su lugar, debe utilizar la propiedad invisible (consulte Texto invisible ) para obtener el mismo efecto.

Por la misma razón, las carcasas de control de trabajos no funcionarán cuando se use una tubería. Consulte process-connection-type en Procesos asíncronos .

The following commands and functions mostly provide compatibility with old versions of Emacs. They work by calling set-face-attribute. Values of t and nil (or omitted) for their frame argument are handled just like set-face-attribute and face-attribute. The commands read their arguments using the minibuffer, if called interactively.
trans-unit.target: Los siguientes comandos y funciones proporcionan principalmente compatibilidad con versiones antiguas de Emacs. Funcionan llamando a set-face-attribute . Los valores de t y nil (u omitidos) para su argumento de frame se manejan como set-face-attribute y face-attribute . Los comandos leen sus argumentos usando el minibúfer, si se llaman de forma interactiva.

trans-unit.source: The following commands can be used to cycle through the global buffer list, much like bury-buffer and unbury-buffer. However, they cycle according to the specified window’s history list, rather than the global buffer list. In addition, they restore window-specific window start and point positions, and may show a buffer even if it is already shown in another window. The switch-to-prev-buffer command, in particular, is used by replace-buffer-in-windows, bury-buffer and quit-window to find a replacement buffer for a window.
trans-unit.target: Los siguientes comandos se pueden utilizar para recorrer la lista de búfer global, al igual que bury-buffer y unbury-buffer . Sin embargo, funcionan según la lista de historial de la ventana especificada, en lugar de la lista de búfer global. Además, restauran las posiciones de inicio y punto de la ventana específicas de la ventana, y pueden mostrar un búfer incluso si ya se muestra en otra ventana. El comando switch-to-prev-buffer , en particular, es usado por replace-buffer-in-windows , bury-buffer y quit-window para encontrar un búfer de reemplazo para una ventana.

trans-unit.source: The following function returns the screen coordinates of a buffer position visible in a window:

The following function returns the size in pixels of text as if it were displayed in a given window. This function is used by fit-window-to-buffer and fit-frame-to-buffer (see Resizing Windows) to make a window exactly as large as the text it contains.
The following function returns the window showing the currently active minibuffer.

The following function tells how small a specific window can get taking into account the sizes of its areas and the values of window-min-height, window-min-width and window-size-fixed (see Preserving Window Sizes).
The following function uses the current buffer for temporary display:
The following functions add a button using an overlay (see Overlays) to hold the button properties:
The following functions are responsible for installing the user’s customization settings for variables and faces, respectively. When the user invokes ‘

The following functions are similar, but using text properties (see Text Properties) to hold the button properties. Such buttons do not add markers to the buffer, so editing in the buffer does not slow down if there is an extremely large numbers of buttons. However, if there is an existing face text property on the text (e.g., a face assigned by Font Lock mode), the button face may not be visible. Both of these functions return the starting position of the new button.
The following functions are specialized for handling floating-point numbers:
The following functions are useful for programmatically enabling and disabling themes:
The following functions can be used to access symbol properties.
The following functions can be used to determine whether a given window has any adjacent windows.
The following functions can be used to manipulate property lists. They all compare property names using eq.
The following functions can be used to obtain information about a font. For these functions, the <var>font</var> argument can be a font object, a font entity, or a font spec.
The following functions can be used to relate a set of frame-relative coordinates to a window:
The following functions can be used to retrieve a child window of an internal window, and the siblings of a child window.
The following functions can be used to work with this structure. Each function takes a
The following functions can be useful to locate a window within its frame.
The following functions create strings, either from scratch, or by putting strings together, or by taking them apart.

The following functions examine the attributes of a face. They mostly provide compatibility with old versions of Emacs. If you don’t specify frame, they refer to the selected frame; t refers to the default data for new frames. They return unspecified if the face doesn’t define any value for that attribute. If inherit is nil, only an attribute directly defined by the face is returned. If inherit is non-nil, any faces specified by its :inherit attribute are considered as well, and if inherit is a face or a list of faces, then they are also considered, until a specified attribute is found. To ensure that the return value is always specified, use a value of default for inherit.

The following functions implement a higher-level interface to face-remapping-alist. Most Lisp code should use these functions instead of setting face-remapping-alist directly, to avoid trampling on remappings applied elsewhere. These functions are intended for buffer-local remappings, so they all make face-remapping-alist buffer-local as a side-effect. They manage face-remapping-alist entries of the form
The following functions may be used to manipulate and query the watch functions for a variable.
